Linear Submodular Maximization with Bandit Feedback

Wenjing Chen Department of Computer Science & Engineering, Texas A&M University Victoria G. Crawford Department of Computer Science & Engineering, Texas A&M University
Abstract

Submodular optimization with bandit feedback has recently been studied in a variety of contexts. In a number of real-world applications such as diversified recommender systems and data summarization, the submodular function exhibits additional linear structure. We consider developing approximation algorithms for the maximization of a submodular objective function f:2U→ℝ≥0:𝑓→superscript2𝑈subscriptℝabsent0f:2^{U}\to\mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}italic_f : 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where f=∑i=1dwi⁢Fi𝑓superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖f=\sum_{i=1}^{d}w_{i}F_{i}italic_f = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. It is assumed that we have value oracle access to the functions Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, but the coefficients wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are unknown, and f𝑓fitalic_f can only be accessed via noisy queries. We develop algorithms for this setting inspired by adaptive allocation algorithms in the best-arm identification for linear bandit, with approximation guarantees arbitrarily close to the setting where we have value oracle access to f𝑓fitalic_f. Finally, we empirically demonstrate that our algorithms make vast improvements in terms of sample efficiency compared to algorithms that do not exploit the linear structure of f𝑓fitalic_f on instances of move recommendation.

1 Introduction

Submodular set functions satisfy a diminishing returns property that arises in many optimization problems in machine learning such as those involving coverage functions (Bateni et al., 2017), data summarization (Lin and Bilmes, 2011; Tschiatschek et al., 2014), facility location  (Lindgren et al., 2016), viral marketing in social networks (Kempe et al., 2003), and recommendation systems (Leskovec et al., 2007; El-Arini and Guestrin, 2011). A set function f:2U→ℝ:𝑓→superscript2𝑈ℝf:2^{U}\to\mathbb{R}italic_f : 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R is submodular if for every X⊆Y⊆U𝑋𝑌𝑈X\subseteq Y\subseteq Uitalic_X ⊆ italic_Y ⊆ italic_U and for every x∈U∖Y𝑥𝑈𝑌x\in U\setminus Yitalic_x ∈ italic_U ∖ italic_Y, we have f⁢(X∪{x})−f⁢(X)≥f⁢(Y∪{x})−f⁢(Y)𝑓𝑋𝑥𝑓𝑋𝑓𝑌𝑥𝑓𝑌f(X\cup\{x\})-f(X)\geq f(Y\cup\{x\})-f(Y)italic_f ( italic_X ∪ { italic_x } ) - italic_f ( italic_X ) ≥ italic_f ( italic_Y ∪ { italic_x } ) - italic_f ( italic_Y ). In addition, f𝑓fitalic_f is often monotone, i.e., f⁢(Y)≥f⁢(X)𝑓𝑌𝑓𝑋f(Y)\geq f(X)italic_f ( italic_Y ) ≥ italic_f ( italic_X ) for every X⊂Y𝑋𝑌X\subset Yitalic_X ⊂ italic_Y. Among the most widely considered formulations is the NP-hard monotone submodular maximization problem with a cardinality constraint Nemhauser et al. (1978): Given budget κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ, find arg⁡max|S|≤κ⁡f⁢(S)subscript𝑆𝜅𝑓𝑆\arg\max_{|S|\leq\kappa}f(S)roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S | ≤ italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_S ). The setting of most existing work on SM is that we have value oracle access to f𝑓fitalic_f, and algorithms may query any subset X⊂U𝑋𝑈X\subset Uitalic_X ⊂ italic_U and the value of f⁢(X)𝑓𝑋f(X)italic_f ( italic_X ) is returned.

However, in many applications it is not realistic to assume that we have value oracle access to f𝑓fitalic_f, but rather that we can only query f𝑓fitalic_f approximately or subject to some noise (Kempe et al., 2003; Singla et al., 2016; Horel and Singer, 2016; Hassidim and Singer, 2017a; Parambath et al., 2018; Peng, 2021) Within this broad area of noisy access to f𝑓fitalic_f, one important line of work consider the development of algorithms for the special case that f𝑓fitalic_f has additional linear structure (Yue and Guestrin, 2011; Yu et al., 2016; Chen et al., 2017; Hiranandani et al., 2020). In particular, the setting and problem is described below.

Definition 1 (Linear Submodular Maximization with a Cardinality Constraint (SM)).

Let U𝑈Uitalic_U be a universe of elements of size n𝑛nitalic_n. Suppose we have d𝑑ditalic_d monotone and submodular functions denoted as Fi:2U→ℝ:subscript𝐹𝑖→superscript2𝑈ℝF_{i}:2^{U}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT : 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R for i=1,2,…,d𝑖12…𝑑i=1,2,...,ditalic_i = 1 , 2 , … , italic_d. The objective function f:2U→ℝ:𝑓→superscript2𝑈ℝf:2^{U}\rightarrow\mathbb{R}italic_f : 2 start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_U end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT → blackboard_R is a weighted sum of the d𝑑ditalic_d submodular functions, i.e. f⁢(S)=∑i=1dwi⁢Fi⁢(S)=FT⁢(S)⁢w𝑓𝑆superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝑆superscriptF𝑇𝑆wf(S)=\sum_{i=1}^{d}w_{i}F_{i}(S)=\textbf{F}^{T}(S)\textbf{w}italic_f ( italic_S ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ) = F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_S ) w, where F⁢(S)=(F1⁢(S),F2⁢(S),…,Fd⁢(S))TF𝑆superscriptsubscript𝐹1𝑆subscript𝐹2𝑆…subscript𝐹𝑑𝑆𝑇\textbf{F}(S)=(F_{1}(S),F_{2}(S),...,F_{d}(S))^{T}F ( italic_S ) = ( italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ) , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ) , … , italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, w=(w1,w2,…,wd)Twsuperscriptsubscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2…subscript𝑤𝑑𝑇\textbf{w}=(w_{1},w_{2},...,w_{d})^{T}w = ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and wi≥0subscript𝑤𝑖0w_{i}\geq 0italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ 0 for any i∈[d]𝑖delimited-[]𝑑i\in[d]italic_i ∈ [ italic_d ]. SM is then defined to be, given budget κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ, find arg⁡max|S|≤κ⁡f⁢(S)subscript𝑆𝜅𝑓𝑆\arg\max_{|S|\leq\kappa}f(S)roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_S | ≤ italic_κ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_S ).

Notice that f𝑓fitalic_f is also monotone and submodular, since it is the linear sum of monotone submodular functions. It is assumed that we have value oracle access to each of the basis functions Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and we can query them on any subset S⊆U𝑆𝑈S\subseteq Uitalic_S ⊆ italic_U, but the weight vector w=(w1,w2,…,wd)Twsuperscriptsubscript𝑤1subscript𝑤2…subscript𝑤𝑑𝑇\textbf{w}=(w_{1},w_{2},...,w_{d})^{T}w = ( italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is unknown. We do not have oracle access to f𝑓fitalic_f, but we may make i.i.d. R-sub-Gaussian noisy queries to f𝑓fitalic_f where the expectation is the true value of f𝑓fitalic_f. An important application of this setting is recommendation systems, which we will more thoroughly describe in Section 2. These assumptions on the structure of f𝑓fitalic_f and noise fall into the well-studied linear bandit model (Soare et al., 2014; Xu et al., 2018), as we will explain in more detail in Section 2. The focus of existing work on SM in this setting is integrating linear bandit strategies and algorithms for SM together in order to select a subset X⊆U𝑋𝑈X\subseteq Uitalic_X ⊆ italic_U over a series of iterations that minimizes regret (the online regret minimization setting) (Yue and Guestrin, 2011; Yu et al., 2016; Chen et al., 2017; Hiranandani et al., 2020). Existing works emphasize the online regret minimization setting, wherein the agent strives to select a solution set with high expected function values while exploring new sets.

In the online regret minimization setting, a solution set is selected at each iteration and some corresponding noisy feedback from f𝑓fitalic_f is returned. It is assumed that there is a penalty to choosing a bad set, e.g. a set with low f𝑓fitalic_f value is recommended to a user, and so a balance between exploration (sampling in order to better estimate w) and exploitation (choosing sets at each iteration, e.g. to recommend to a user, that are believed to be of high value) is used in order to select sets. On the other hand, an alternative to the regret minimization setting is that of the pure exploration linear bandit (Soare et al., 2014; Xu et al., 2018), where as few noisy samples as possible are taken in orders to arrive at a good solution quickly. We depart from existing literature on linear submodular bandit in that we do not use the online regret minimization setting, but instead make use of ideas from pure exploration linear bandit. More specifically, our goal is to provide a solution set with a PAC-style theoretical guarantee Even-Dar et al. (2002); Kalyanakrishnan et al. (2012), where the bandit algorithm identifies an ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-optimal arm with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, in as few samples as possible. This type of problem has been previously studied in the submodular optimization literature by Singla et al. in the general case where f𝑓fitalic_f does not have linear structure. But the linear structure of f𝑓fitalic_f allows us to develop algorithms that make significantly fewer noisy samples (as will be demonstrated in Section 5), because we are able to learn the unknown vector w as more and more noisy samples are made.

In particular, the contributions of our paper are as follows: (i) We propose and analyze the algorithm Linear Greedy (LG), which is inspired by the standard greedy algorithm, but proceeds as κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ rounds of best-arm-identification problems in the linear bandit setting. We prove that the exact function value of the output solution set of LG S𝑆Sitalic_S is arbitrarily close to the optimal approximation guarantee of 1−1/e11𝑒1-1/e1 - 1 / italic_e for cardinality constrained submodular maximization (Nemhauser et al., 1978). In addition, LG chooses an optimal sample allocation strategy, and we prove a bound on the total number of noisy samples required by LG. (ii) We next propose and analyse the algorthm Linear Threshold Greedy (LinTG) which is based on the threshold greedy algorithm of Badanidiyuru and Vondrák (2014), but we propose a new linear bandit strategy in a novel setting that is distinct from best-arm-identification. LinTG is more efficient compared to LG from an algorithmic perspective, but additionally the linear bandit strategy itself is more efficient in several ways. Similar to LG, LinTG is proven to return a solution set S𝑆Sitalic_S that is arbitrarily close to 1−1/e11𝑒1-1/e1 - 1 / italic_e. (iii) Finally, we compare our algorithms to several alternative approaches to this problem on instances of movie recommendation. We find that our algorithms make significant improvements in terms of sample complexity.

1.1 Related Work

There has been a great line of work on noisy submodular maximization Horel and Singer (2016); Hassidim and Singer (2017b); Crawford et al. (2019). Among these works, the most related setting assumes the noisy feedback is i.i.d R𝑅Ritalic_R-sub-Gaussian, which is also referred to as bandit feedback Singla et al. (2016); Karimi et al. (2017). The problem is also referred to as submodular bandit, which is a specific type of combinatorial multi-armed bandit problem with the reward function assumed to be submodular Chen et al. (2017); Takemori et al. (2020); Hiranandani et al. (2020). The main focus of these works are regret minimization. Among the works studying submodular bandit, the linear submodular bandit is a specific problem with the same objective function as us Yue and Guestrin (2011); Takemori et al. (2020); Yu et al. (2016), i.e., the objective function f𝑓fitalic_f can be expressed by the linear sum of known submodular functions with unknown weights. The problem was first introduced by Yue and Guestrin (2011), who studied the problem with the goal of regret minimization. Under this setting, the strategy is to explore new choices of the subsets while also exploiting previous samples to select good ones. Therefore, the algorithm should be encouraged to choose the sets with higher function values while the main focus of our paper is to study the linear submodular bandit under best-arm identification setting, where the objective is to find the best solution set in fewer queries. One obvious approach to this problem is to simply take sufficiently many noisy samples so that f𝑓fitalic_f is approximated very closely for all sets that are to be queried, and then apply existing algorithms for SM on the approximation of f𝑓fitalic_f. The downsides of such an approach is that not only is it unnecessary to approximate f𝑓fitalic_f so closely when making decisions during an algorithm, but this approach does not exploit the linear structure of f𝑓fitalic_f. A difficulty with such algorithms is that the large number of noisy samples can make such an approach impractical.

Another related line of work is the problem of identifying the best element in linear bandit (The arms are single elements in the universe.), which is first studied in Soare et al. (2014). The authors proposed static allocation strategies and adaptive strategies based on successive elimination. Later on, there are a large line of works that proposed more adaptive algorithms Xu et al. (2018); Degenne et al. (2020). Xu et al. (2018) proposed an algorithm named LinGap which is claimed to be fully adaptive and performed better than those in Soare et al. (2014). Degenne et al. (2020) proposed the first algorithm that is asymptotically optimal.

2 Preliminaries

In this section, we present the basic setup for our problem, including motivating examples, a description of the linear bandit setting, and related technical background that will be used for our algorithms. First, we provide some additional information about our problem formulation. We assume that the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm of w is bounded by S𝑆Sitalic_S, and the l2subscript𝑙2l_{2}italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT norm of F⁢(s)F𝑠\textbf{F}(s)F ( italic_s ) is bounded by L𝐿Litalic_L for any s∈U𝑠𝑈s\in Uitalic_s ∈ italic_U.

For any S⊆U𝑆𝑈S\subseteq Uitalic_S ⊆ italic_U and x∈U𝑥𝑈x\in Uitalic_x ∈ italic_U, the sampling result of the marginal gain Δ⁢f⁢(S,x)Δ𝑓𝑆𝑥\Delta f(S,x)roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_x ) is i.i.d R𝑅Ritalic_R-sub-Gaussian with expectation Δ⁢f⁢(S,x)Δ𝑓𝑆𝑥\Delta f(S,x)roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_x ). Let us denote the t𝑡titalic_t-th independent samples of Δ⁢f⁢(S,x)Δ𝑓𝑆𝑥\Delta f(S,x)roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_x ) as Δ⁢ft⁢(S,x)Δsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑆𝑥\Delta f_{t}(S,x)roman_Δ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ). We assume the noisy queries can be expressed as Δ⁢ft⁢(S,x)=∑i=1dwi⁢Δ⁢Fi⁢(S,x)+ξt=Δ⁢FT⁢(S,x)⁢w+ξtΔsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑆𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝑤𝑖Δsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑆𝑥subscript𝜉𝑡ΔsuperscriptF𝑇𝑆𝑥wsubscript𝜉𝑡\Delta f_{t}(S,x)=\sum_{i=1}^{d}w_{i}\Delta F_{i}(S,x)+\xi_{t}=\Delta\textbf{F% }^{T}(S,x)\textbf{w}+\xi_{t}roman_Δ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ) + italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Δ F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ) w + italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, where ξtsubscript𝜉𝑡\xi_{t}italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are i.i.d zero-mean noise and R𝑅Ritalic_R-sub-Gaussian. Therefore we have that 𝔼⁢Δ⁢ft⁢(S,x)=∑i=1dwi⁢Δ⁢Fi⁢(S,x)=Δ⁢f⁢(S,x)𝔼Δsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑆𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝑤𝑖Δsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑆𝑥Δ𝑓𝑆𝑥\mathbb{E}\Delta f_{t}(S,x)=\sum_{i=1}^{d}w_{i}\Delta F_{i}(S,x)=\Delta f(S,x)blackboard_E roman_Δ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ) = roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_x ). Linear submodular functions arise in a wide range of applications including recommender systems, weighted coverage, and facility location. Next, we describe the application of the recommender system as an example to illustrate our problem setting.

2.1 Motivating application: diversified recommender systems

In this application, the user examines the recommended list of S𝑆Sitalic_S of κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ items from the first item to the last, clicks on the first attractive item, and does not examine the rest. Herein, the submodular function is the expected total clicks from recommending the list of items. Suppose Fi⁢(S)subscript𝐹𝑖𝑆F_{i}(S)italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ) denotes a submodular function quantifying the incorporation of topic i𝑖iitalic_i within the recommended item set S𝑆Sitalic_S which is usually modeled by the probabilistic coverage model Yue and Guestrin (2011); Hiranandani et al. (2020), and that wisubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the preference of the user towards the topic i𝑖iitalic_i and is unknown to the algorithm. Then f⁢(S)𝑓𝑆f(S)italic_f ( italic_S ) is defined as f⁢(S)=∑i∈dwi⁢Fi⁢(S)𝑓𝑆subscript𝑖𝑑subscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝐹𝑖𝑆f(S)=\sum_{i\in d}w_{i}F_{i}(S)italic_f ( italic_S ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S ). By definition, we have that ∑iwi=1subscript𝑖subscript𝑤𝑖1\sum_{i}w_{i}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. Therefore, ‖w‖2≤‖w‖1=1subscriptnormw2subscriptnormw11||\textbf{w}||_{2}\leq||\textbf{w}||_{1}=1| | w | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ | | w | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and we can set S=1𝑆1S=1italic_S = 1.

Next, we list necessary notation: (i). Let us denote the marginal gain of adding element x∈U𝑥𝑈x\in Uitalic_x ∈ italic_U to a set S⊆U𝑆𝑈S\subseteq Uitalic_S ⊆ italic_U as Δ⁢f⁢(S,x)Δ𝑓𝑆𝑥\Delta f(S,x)roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_x ), i.e., Δ⁢f⁢(S,x):=f⁢(S∪{x})−f⁢(S)assignΔ𝑓𝑆𝑥𝑓𝑆𝑥𝑓𝑆\Delta f(S,x):=f(S\cup\{x\})-f(S)roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_x ) := italic_f ( italic_S ∪ { italic_x } ) - italic_f ( italic_S ). Therefore, by definition, we have that Δ⁢f⁢(S,x)=∑i=1dwi⁢Δ⁢Fi⁢(S,x)=Δ⁢F⁢(S,x)T⁢wΔ𝑓𝑆𝑥superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑑subscript𝑤𝑖Δsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑆𝑥ΔFsuperscript𝑆𝑥𝑇w\Delta f(S,x)=\sum_{i=1}^{d}w_{i}\Delta F_{i}(S,x)=\Delta\textbf{F}(S,x)^{T}% \textbf{w}roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ) = roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w. Here Δ⁢F⁢(S,x)=(Δ⁢F1⁢(S,x),…,Δ⁢Fd⁢(S,x))TΔF𝑆𝑥superscriptΔsubscript𝐹1𝑆𝑥…Δsubscript𝐹𝑑𝑆𝑥𝑇\Delta\textbf{F}(S,x)=(\Delta F_{1}(S,x),...,\Delta F_{d}(S,x))^{T}roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_x ) = ( roman_Δ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ) , … , roman_Δ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. (ii) When set S𝑆Sitalic_S is clear from context, we also use FxsubscriptF𝑥\textbf{F}_{x}F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to denote Δ⁢F⁢(S,x)ΔF𝑆𝑥\Delta\textbf{F}(S,x)roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_x ), which is the marginal gain vector of adding new element x𝑥xitalic_x to S𝑆Sitalic_S. Throughout this paper, we define the matrix norm as ‖x‖A=xT⁢AxsubscriptnormxAsuperscriptx𝑇Ax||\textbf{x}||_{\textbf{A}}=\sqrt{\textbf{x}^{T}\textbf{A}\textbf{x}}| | x | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = square-root start_ARG x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT bold_A bold_x end_ARG. We use [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n][ italic_n ] to denote the set {1,2,…,n}12…𝑛\{1,2,...,n\}{ 1 , 2 , … , italic_n }. In particular, we use U𝑈Uitalic_U and [n]delimited-[]𝑛[n][ italic_n ] interchangeably.

2.2 The linear bandit setting

Finally, we describe the linear bandit problem and how it can be related to our noisy submodular optimization setting. Suppose there are n𝑛nitalic_n elements in the universe with features x1subscriptx1\textbf{x}_{1}x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, x2subscriptx2\textbf{x}_{2}x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, …., xn∈ℝdsubscriptx𝑛superscriptℝ𝑑\textbf{x}_{n}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. We denote the set of features as 𝒳={x1,x2,…,xn}𝒳subscriptx1subscriptx2…subscriptx𝑛\mathcal{X}=\{\textbf{x}_{1},\textbf{x}_{2},...,\textbf{x}_{n}\}caligraphic_X = { x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUBSCRIPT }. At each step t𝑡titalic_t, the algorithm selects an element at∈[n]subscript𝑎𝑡delimited-[]𝑛a_{t}\in[n]italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_n ], and observe the reward rt=xatT⁢w+ξtsubscript𝑟𝑡superscriptsubscriptxsubscript𝑎𝑡𝑇wsubscript𝜉𝑡r_{t}=\textbf{x}_{a_{t}}^{T}\textbf{w}+\xi_{t}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w + italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Here w is unknown and we assume ‖w‖2≤Ssubscriptnormw2𝑆||\textbf{w}||_{2}\leq S| | w | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_S. We also define the arm selection sequence of the first t𝑡titalic_t steps as Xt=(xa1,xa2,…,xat)TsubscriptX𝑡superscriptsubscriptxsubscript𝑎1subscriptxsubscript𝑎2…subscriptxsubscript𝑎𝑡𝑇\textbf{X}_{t}=(\textbf{x}_{a_{1}},\textbf{x}_{a_{2}},...,\textbf{x}_{a_{t}})^% {T}X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the vector of rewards of the first t𝑡titalic_t steps as Rt=(r1,r2,…,rt)Tsubscript𝑅𝑡superscriptsubscript𝑟1subscript𝑟2…subscript𝑟𝑡𝑇R_{t}=(r_{1},r_{2},...,r_{t})^{T}italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , … , italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. A central component of best-arm identification in the linear bandit setting is having an estimate of the unknown vector w. The regularized least-square estimate of the vector w with some regularizer λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ is thus

w^tλ=(∑i=1txai⁢xaiT+λ⁢I)−1⁢(∑i=1txai⁢ri)=(XtT⁢Xt+λ⁢I)−1⁢(XtT⁢Rt).superscriptsubscript^w𝑡𝜆superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡subscriptxsubscript𝑎𝑖superscriptsubscriptxsubscript𝑎𝑖𝑇𝜆𝐼1superscriptsubscript𝑖1𝑡subscriptxsubscript𝑎𝑖subscript𝑟𝑖superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptX𝑡𝑇subscriptX𝑡𝜆𝐼1superscriptsubscriptX𝑡𝑇subscript𝑅𝑡\displaystyle\hat{\textbf{w}}_{t}^{\lambda}=(\sum_{i=1}^{t}\textbf{x}_{a_{i}}% \textbf{x}_{a_{i}}^{T}+\lambda I)^{-1}(\sum_{i=1}^{t}\textbf{x}_{a_{i}}r_{i})=% (\textbf{X}_{t}^{T}\textbf{X}_{t}+\lambda I)^{-1}(\textbf{X}_{t}^{T}R_{t}).over^ start_ARG w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_λ italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ( X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_λ italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

The matrix XtT⁢Xt+λ⁢IsuperscriptsubscriptX𝑡𝑇subscriptX𝑡𝜆𝐼\textbf{X}_{t}^{T}\textbf{X}_{t}+\lambda IX start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_λ italic_I is defined as AtsubscriptA𝑡\textbf{A}_{t}A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and the vector XtT⁢RtsuperscriptsubscriptX𝑡𝑇subscript𝑅𝑡\textbf{X}_{t}^{T}R_{t}X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is defined as btsubscriptb𝑡\textbf{b}_{t}b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Consequently, wt=At−1⁢btsubscriptw𝑡superscriptsubscriptA𝑡1subscriptb𝑡\textbf{w}_{t}=\textbf{A}_{t}^{-1}\textbf{b}_{t}w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Notice that here the inverse of AtsubscriptA𝑡\textbf{A}_{t}A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT can be updated quickly by using the Woodbury formula in Lemma 11. Here we explain how the linear bandit model can be used in our algorithms. Suppose we choose to sample the marginal gain of adding element stsubscript𝑠𝑡s_{t}italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to subset Stsubscript𝑆𝑡S_{t}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT at time step t𝑡titalic_t, then we can set xat=Δ⁢F⁢(St,st)subscriptxsubscript𝑎𝑡ΔFsubscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝑠𝑡\textbf{x}_{a_{t}}=\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{t},s_{t})x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), the reward rtsubscript𝑟𝑡r_{t}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is thus the noisy marginal gain feedback, i.e., rt=Δ⁢ft⁢(St,st)=Δ⁢F⁢(St,st)T⁢w+ξtsubscript𝑟𝑡Δsubscript𝑓𝑡subscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝑠𝑡ΔFsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑡subscript𝑠𝑡𝑇wsubscript𝜉𝑡r_{t}=\Delta f_{t}(S_{t},s_{t})=\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{t},s_{t})^{T}\textbf{w}+% \xi_{t}italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Δ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_s start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w + italic_ξ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

2.3 Concentration Properties of Estimation of Weight Vector

Our estimate of w is used alongside a concentration inequality that tells us how accurate our estimate is in the form of a confidence interval. In contrast to concentration inequalities such as Hoeffding’s which is for a real-valued random variable, the confidence region in the concentration inequality we use can be geometrically interpreted as a ellipsoid. Pulling different arms results in the shrinking of the confidence region along different directions. The following is the concentration inequality that we will use for our least-squares estimator. The result is obtained from Thm. 2 in Abbasi-Yadkori et al. (2011). The proof can be found in the appendix.

Proposition 1.

Let w^tλsuperscriptsubscript^w𝑡𝜆\hat{\textbf{w}}_{t}^{\lambda}over^ start_ARG w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT be the solution to the regularized least-squares problem with regularizer λ𝜆\lambdaitalic_λ and let Atλ=XtT⁢Xt+λ⁢IsuperscriptsubscriptA𝑡𝜆superscriptsubscriptX𝑡𝑇subscriptX𝑡𝜆I\textbf{A}_{t}^{\lambda}=\textbf{X}_{t}^{T}\textbf{X}_{t}+\lambda\textbf{I}A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_λ I. Then for any N≥0𝑁0N\geq 0italic_N ≥ 0 and every adaptive sequence XtsubscriptX𝑡\textbf{X}_{t}X start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT such that at any step t, xatsubscriptxsubscript𝑎𝑡\textbf{x}_{a_{t}}x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT only depends on past history, we have that with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, it holds that |yT⁢(w^tλ−w)|≤‖y‖(Atλ)−1⁢Ctsuperscripty𝑇superscriptsubscript^w𝑡𝜆wsubscriptnormysuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptA𝑡𝜆1subscript𝐶𝑡|\textbf{y}^{T}(\hat{\textbf{w}}_{t}^{\lambda}-\textbf{w})|\leq||\textbf{y}||_% {(\textbf{A}_{t}^{\lambda})^{-1}}C_{t}| y start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - w ) | ≤ | | y | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for all t≥N𝑡𝑁t\geq Nitalic_t ≥ italic_N and all y∈ℝdysuperscriptℝ𝑑\textbf{y}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}y ∈ blackboard_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT that only depends on past history up to time N𝑁Nitalic_N, where Ctsubscript𝐶𝑡C_{t}italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is defined as

Ct=R⁢2⁢log⁡det(Atλ)12⁢det(λ⁢I)−12δ+λ12⁢S.subscript𝐶𝑡𝑅2superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptA𝑡𝜆12superscript𝜆𝐼12𝛿superscript𝜆12𝑆\displaystyle C_{t}=R\sqrt{2\log\frac{\det(\textbf{A}_{t}^{\lambda})^{\frac{1}% {2}}\det(\lambda I)^{-\frac{1}{2}}}{\delta}}+\lambda^{\frac{1}{2}}S.italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_R square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log divide start_ARG roman_det ( A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_det ( italic_λ italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG end_ARG + italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S .

3 The Standard Greedy Algorithm

In this section, we propose and analyze our first algorithm Linear Greedy (LG), which is inspired by the standard greedy algorithm with the assumption of access to the exact value oracle to f𝑓fitalic_f. In such an algorithm, at each round, an element with the highest marginal gain u=arg⁡maxx∈U⁡f⁢(S,x)𝑢subscript𝑥𝑈𝑓𝑆𝑥u=\arg\max_{x\in U}f(S,x)italic_u = roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_f ( italic_S , italic_x ) is selected and added to the solution set S𝑆Sitalic_S. Since in our problem, f𝑓fitalic_f is only accessible via noisy queries, we develop an algorithm inspired by the best-arm-identification algorithm for multi-armed-bandit of Xu et al. (2018) to select the element to add to the solution set. We provide the algorithm description and overview as follows.

Algorithm overview. We now describe LG, pseudocode for which is given in Algorithm 1. LG proceeds in a series of κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ rounds, with κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ being the input budget, where during each round an element u𝑢uitalic_u of maximum marginal gain is added to the solution with high probability. S𝑆Sitalic_S is the solution set that LG builds, and let Slsubscript𝑆𝑙S_{l}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT be the solution set before the l𝑙litalic_l-th element is added at the end of round l𝑙litalic_l. The element to be added is determined by making a series of noisy queries, i.e. taking samples of noisy marginal gains. We can view the problem of finding a∈U𝑎𝑈a\in Uitalic_a ∈ italic_U such that Δ⁢f⁢(S,a)≥maxu∈U⁡Δ⁢f⁢(S,u)Δ𝑓𝑆𝑎subscript𝑢𝑈Δ𝑓𝑆𝑢\Delta f(S,a)\geq\max_{u\in U}\Delta f(S,u)roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_a ) ≥ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ∈ italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_u ) as a linear bandit problem with n𝑛nitalic_n arms corresponding to the elements of U𝑈Uitalic_U. The set of arms from which we take samples includes all past marginal gains. Our objective is to find an arm a^^𝑎\hat{a}over^ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG that satisfies xa^T⁢w≥maxu∈[n]⁡xuT⁢w−ϵ′subscriptsuperscriptx𝑇^𝑎wsubscript𝑢delimited-[]𝑛subscriptsuperscriptx𝑇𝑢wsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′\textbf{x}^{T}_{\hat{a}}\textbf{w}\geq\max_{u\in[n]}\textbf{x}^{T}_{u}\textbf{% w}-\epsilon^{\prime}x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT over^ start_ARG italic_a end_ARG end_POSTSUBSCRIPT w ≥ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT w - italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT where ϵ′=ϵ/κsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′italic-ϵ𝜅\epsilon^{\prime}=\epsilon/\kappaitalic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_ϵ / italic_κ. LG keeps track of the following throughout its duration: (i) A variable t𝑡titalic_t indicating the total number of samples that have been taken since the beginning of the algorithm, (ii) the matrix A and the vector b for the least-squares estimate of w as described in Section 2.2, and (iii) the total number of noisy samples of the marginal gain Δ⁢f⁢(Sl′,j)Δ𝑓subscript𝑆superscript𝑙′𝑗\Delta f(S_{l^{\prime}},j)roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j ) for each l′∈{1,2,3⁢…,l}superscript𝑙′123…𝑙l^{\prime}\in\{1,2,3...,l\}italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ { 1 , 2 , 3 … , italic_l } and j∈[n]𝑗delimited-[]𝑛j\in[n]italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] denoted as Tl′,usubscript𝑇superscript𝑙′𝑢T_{l^{\prime},u}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_u end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

We now describe a round of LG in detail. The round begins by taking a single noisy sample of the marginal gain of adding each element to the current solution S𝑆Sitalic_S (Lines 7 to 12). Next, LG proceeds to a loop (Lines 14 to 27) where each iteration corresponds to a single noisy marginal gain sample, and the loop exits once the highest marginal gain element is identified with high probability (when Line 20 is satisfied). At the beginning of the loop, the guess of w is computed based on the procedure described in Section 2.2 (Line 15). Next in the loop, LG identifies the best marginal gain vector to sample from the current and past set of marginal gains, i.e. the set {Δ⁢F⁢(Sl′,a)}l′∈[l],a∈[n]subscriptΔFsubscript𝑆superscript𝑙′𝑎formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑙′delimited-[]𝑙𝑎delimited-[]𝑛\{\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{l^{\prime}},a)\}_{l^{\prime}\in[l],a\in[n]}{ roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_l ] , italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT (Lines 16 to 19). This is done as follows: Two elements itsubscript𝑖𝑡i_{t}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and jtsubscript𝑗𝑡j_{t}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the universe U𝑈Uitalic_U are selected where itsubscript𝑖𝑡i_{t}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the element with the highest estimated marginal gain according to our current estimate of w (Line 16), and jtsubscript𝑗𝑡j_{t}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the element whose upper confidence bound of the direction Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,it)ΔF𝑆𝑗ΔF𝑆subscript𝑖𝑡\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i_{t})roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) is the highest. The upper confidence bound is given by Δ⁢F⁢(S,jt)T⁢w^t−Δ⁢F⁢(S,it)T⁢w^t+βt⁢(jt,it)ΔFsuperscript𝑆subscript𝑗𝑡𝑇subscript^w𝑡ΔFsuperscript𝑆subscript𝑖𝑡𝑇subscript^w𝑡subscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝑗𝑡subscript𝑖𝑡\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j_{t})^{T}\hat{\textbf{w}}_{t}-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i_{t})^{T% }\hat{\textbf{w}}_{t}+\beta_{t}(j_{t},i_{t})roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) where βt⁢(i,j)=Ct⁢‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)‖At−1subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖𝑗subscript𝐶𝑡subscriptnormΔF𝑆𝑗ΔF𝑆𝑖superscriptsubscriptA𝑡1\beta_{t}(i,j)=C_{t}||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)||_{\textbf{A% }_{t}^{-1}}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) = italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and Ct=(R⁢2⁢log⁡det(Atλ)12⁢det(λ⁢I)−12δ+λ12⁢S)subscript𝐶𝑡𝑅2superscriptsuperscriptsubscriptA𝑡𝜆12superscript𝜆𝐼12𝛿superscript𝜆12𝑆C_{t}=(R\sqrt{2\log\frac{\det(\textbf{A}_{t}^{\lambda})^{\frac{1}{2}}\det(% \lambda I)^{-\frac{1}{2}}}{\delta}}+\lambda^{\frac{1}{2}}S)italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_R square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log divide start_ARG roman_det ( A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_λ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_det ( italic_λ italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG end_ARG + italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S ). We then follow a strategy proposed by Xu et al. (2018), and discussed in the appendix in Section A.2.1, in order to select the marginal gain vector that makes the confidence interval ‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)‖At−1subscriptnormΔF𝑆𝑖ΔF𝑆𝑗superscriptsubscriptA𝑡1||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)||_{\textbf{A}_{t}^{-1}}| | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to shrink as fast as possible. In particular, we choose the asymptotic-optimal ratio for decreasing the confidence interval ‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)‖At−1subscriptnormΔF𝑆𝑖ΔF𝑆𝑗superscriptsubscriptA𝑡1||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)||_{\textbf{A}_{t}^{-1}}| | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when the number of samples goes to infinity. We denote the sampling ratio of the marginal gain vector Δ⁢F⁢(Sl′,a)ΔFsubscript𝑆superscript𝑙′𝑎\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{l^{\prime}},a)roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a ) at the round l𝑙litalic_l for estimating the direction of Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)ΔF𝑆𝑖ΔF𝑆𝑗\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) as p∗⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)superscript𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ). We pull the arm so that the number of samples of arms is close to the ratio p𝑝pitalic_p. More specifically,

(lt,at)=arg⁡minl′∈[l],a∈[n]:pl′,a∗⁢(it,jt)>0⁡Tl′,ap∗⁢(l′,a|l,it,jt).subscript𝑙𝑡subscript𝑎𝑡subscript:formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑙′delimited-[]𝑙𝑎delimited-[]𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑝superscript𝑙′𝑎subscript𝑖𝑡subscript𝑗𝑡0subscript𝑇superscript𝑙′𝑎superscript𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙subscript𝑖𝑡subscript𝑗𝑡\displaystyle(l_{t},a_{t})=\arg\min_{l^{\prime}\in[l],a\in[n]:p^{*}_{l^{\prime% },a}(i_{t},j_{t})>0}\frac{T_{l^{\prime},a}}{p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i_{t},j_{t})}.( italic_l start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_l ] , italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] : italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) > 0 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) end_ARG .

This concludes the description of our algorithm LG.

Technical challenges. We now discuss the technical difficulties of developing LG. It should be noted that the portion of LG where we are repeatedly making noisy queries in order to determine the element of approximately highest marginal gain with high probability could be replaced by any existing algorithm for ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ-approximate best-arm-identification in linear bandit where the arms correspond to the marginal gains of adding each of the n𝑛nitalic_n elements of U𝑈Uitalic_U to the current solution S𝑆Sitalic_S. In this case, each round of LG would be a new instance of linear bandit. In particular, we develop an algorithm using the static allocation strategy as the subroutine in Section A.1. However, such algorithms overlook that the weight vector estimated in different rounds of the algorithm are the same and don’t reuse samples gained from the past rounds while our algorithm LG is different because we do not view each round of LG as a new instance of linear bandit, but instead we use information gained about w from past rounds of the greedy algorithm. In addition, LG may sample marginal gains corresponding to arms of the previous rounds of the greedy algorithm. Thus, our contribution extends beyond merely integrating best-arm identification into the greedy algorithm. We also develop an algorithm, inspired by Xu et al. (2018), which efficiently reuses samples from previous rounds, thereby enhancing the algorithm’s performance and efficiency.

Theoretical Guarantees. Finally, we present the theoretical guarantees of LG. Here we denote the total number of samples of Δ⁢F⁢(Sl′,a)ΔFsubscript𝑆superscript𝑙′𝑎\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{l^{\prime}},a)roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a ) before iteration l𝑙litalic_l as Nl′,a(l)superscriptsubscript𝑁superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙N_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, and the total number of samples before iteration l𝑙litalic_l as N(l)=∑l′∈[l],a∈[n]Nl′,a(l)superscript𝑁𝑙subscriptformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑙′delimited-[]𝑙𝑎delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑁superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙N^{(l)}=\sum_{l^{\prime}\in[l],a\in[n]}N_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_l ] , italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Moreover, we define Δl,i=maxa∈[n]⁡Δ⁢F⁢(Sl,a)T⁢w−Δ⁢F⁢(Sl,i)T⁢wsubscriptΔ𝑙𝑖subscript𝑎delimited-[]𝑛ΔFsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑙𝑎𝑇wΔFsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑙𝑖𝑇w\Delta_{l,i}=\max_{a\in[n]}\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{l},a)^{T}\textbf{w}-\Delta% \textbf{F}(S_{l},i)^{T}\textbf{w}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w - roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w. Then we have the following results. The proof is deferred to Section A.2 in the appendix.

Theorem 2.

With probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, the following statements hold:

  1. 1.

    The exact function value of the output solution set S𝑆Sitalic_S satisfies that f⁢(S)≥(1−e−1)⁢f⁢(O⁢P⁢T)−ϵ.𝑓𝑆1superscript𝑒1𝑓𝑂𝑃𝑇italic-ϵf(S)\geq(1-e^{-1})f(OPT)-\epsilon.italic_f ( italic_S ) ≥ ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_O italic_P italic_T ) - italic_ϵ . Here O⁢P⁢T𝑂𝑃𝑇OPTitalic_O italic_P italic_T is an optimal solution to the SM problem;

  2. 2.

    During each round in LG, as the number of samples increases, the confidence region would shrink, and the stopping condition B⁢(t)≤ϵ/κ𝐵𝑡italic-ϵ𝜅B(t)\leq\epsilon/\kappaitalic_B ( italic_t ) ≤ italic_ϵ / italic_κ would be met ultimately.     number of samples, where M(l)=16⁢Hϵ(l)⁢R2⁢L2λ⁢log⁡(1δ)+32⁢(Hϵ(l))2⁢R4⁢L4λ2+2⁢(N(l)+n⁢l)⁢L2λ⁢d+2superscript𝑀𝑙16superscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑙superscript𝑅2superscript𝐿2𝜆1𝛿32superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑙2superscript𝑅4superscript𝐿4superscript𝜆22superscript𝑁𝑙𝑛𝑙superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑑2M^{(l)}=\frac{16H_{\epsilon}^{(l)}R^{2}L^{2}}{\lambda}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})+% \frac{32(H_{\epsilon}^{(l)})^{2}R^{4}L^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}+\frac{2(N^{(l)}+nl)L^% {2}}{\lambda d}+2italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 16 italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) + divide start_ARG 32 ( italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_n italic_l ) italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG + 2. Now we discuss the sample complexity. First of all, if we set Nl′,a(l)=0superscriptsubscript𝑁superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙0N_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)}=0italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 0, then the result is reduced to the case where we don’t utilize the samples of the marginal gains from the past rounds. Compared with this case, our sample complexity of using past data can be improved by at most Nl′,a(l)superscriptsubscript𝑁superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙N_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT from the past rounds for each l′,asuperscript𝑙′𝑎l^{\prime},aitalic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a while only sacrificing the factor of O⁢(log⁡(N(l)))𝑂superscript𝑁𝑙O(\log(N^{(l)}))italic_O ( roman_log ( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ). On the other hand, as discussed in the algorithm overview, selecting an element to add to the solution set corresponds to a best-arm identification problem in linear bandits. Thus, we can compare our results with the element-selecting procedure being replaced by LinGapE in Xu et al. (2018), which does not leverage samples of noisy marginal gains from previous rounds of the greedy algorithm. The sample complexity of LinGapE is τ2=4⁢Hϵ(l)⁢R2⁢(2⁢log⁡κ⁢n2δ+d⁢log⁡M(l))+nsubscript𝜏24superscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑙superscript𝑅22𝜅superscript𝑛2𝛿𝑑superscript𝑀𝑙𝑛\tau_{2}=4H_{\epsilon}^{(l)}R^{2}(2\log\frac{\kappa n^{2}}{\delta}+d\log M^{(l% )})+nitalic_τ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 4 italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 roman_log divide start_ARG italic_κ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG + italic_d roman_log italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + italic_n, which is worse than the sample complexity of LG in the case where we don’t utilize samples from the past, and the set of samples we can take is limited to the set of {Δ⁢F⁢(S,a)}a∈[n]subscriptΔF𝑆𝑎𝑎delimited-[]𝑛\{\Delta\textbf{F}(S,a)\}_{a\in[n]}{ roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_a ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT by a factor of O⁢(log⁡n2)𝑂superscript𝑛2O(\log n^{2})italic_O ( roman_log italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ).

On the other hand, we have to notice that to find the asymptotic sample selection ratio p∗⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)superscript𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ), the algorithm involves solving a linear programming problem for each i,j𝑖𝑗i,jitalic_i , italic_j at each round l𝑙litalic_l to find {p∗⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)}l′∈[l],a∈[n]subscriptsuperscript𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗formulae-sequencesuperscript𝑙′delimited-[]𝑙𝑎delimited-[]𝑛\{p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)\}_{l^{\prime}\in[l],a\in[n]}{ italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_l ] , italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, which results in solving a total of O⁢(κ⁢n2)𝑂𝜅superscript𝑛2O(\kappa n^{2})italic_O ( italic_κ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) number of the optimization problems. In particular, if we replace the allocation ratio p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with any other ratio p𝑝pitalic_p, the result in the theorem would still holds, with the value of ρi,jlsubscriptsuperscript𝜌𝑙𝑖𝑗\rho^{l}_{i,j}italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT being replaced by ‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)‖Λi,j−12subscriptsuperscriptnormΔF𝑆𝑖ΔF𝑆𝑗2superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑖𝑗1||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)||^{2}_{\Lambda_{i,j}^{-1}}| | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) | | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Λi,j−1superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑖𝑗1{\Lambda_{i,j}^{-1}}roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is defined in (8).

4 Threshold Greedy with Adaptive Allocation strategy

In the last section, we present our algorithm LG which is based on the standard greedy algorithm but with linear bandit feedback. However, the implementation of LG poses several challenges in terms of its scalability: (i) Finding the allocation strategy in LG necessitates solving O⁢(κ⁢n2)𝑂𝜅superscript𝑛2O(\kappa n^{2})italic_O ( italic_κ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) linear programming problems, (ii) LG requires updating the inverse of matrix A and confidence interval every time an arm is pulled, (iii) LG is sensitive to the gap between the marginal gains of different elements and therefore may need many samples in the case that there exist elements that have an expected reward close to optimal, (iv) the standard greedy algorithm is less efficient compared to alternative greedy algorithms even in the exact value oracle setting. Motivated by these weaknesses of LG, we introduce an alternative algorithm Linear Threshold Greedy (LinTG) which is based on the threshold greedy algorithm of Badanidiyuru and Vondrák (2014), but incorporates a linear bandit strategy.

We now describe LinTG, pseudocode for which is given in Algorithm 2. LinTG proceeds in a series of rounds (Lines 12 to 35), each round corresponding to a threshold value w𝑤witalic_w. w𝑤witalic_w is initialized to be an approximation of the maximum f𝑓fitalic_f value of a singleton in U𝑈Uitalic_U. During each round of LinTG, we iterate over the ground set U𝑈Uitalic_U and make a decision about whether to add each element a∈U𝑎𝑈a\in Uitalic_a ∈ italic_U to our solution S𝑆Sitalic_S or not depending on whether the marginal gain Δ⁢f⁢(S,a)Δ𝑓𝑆𝑎\Delta f(S,a)roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_a ) is above w𝑤witalic_w. LinTG decides whether to add each a∈U𝑎𝑈a\in Uitalic_a ∈ italic_U to S𝑆Sitalic_S or not on Lines 14 to 33 based on a sampling procedure in a linear bandit-like setting, and is analogous to the best-arm-identification procedure in LG. Throughout the algorithm, we keep track of the following parameters: the covariance matrix A, vector b, and the set of marginal gain vectors to sample from, which is denoted as 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. Here we denote the size of 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X as m𝑚mitalic_m. In this algorithm, 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X includes all the past marginal gains that have been evaluated. Let us denote 𝒳={Δ⁢F⁢(Si,ai)}i∈[m]𝒳subscriptΔFsubscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖𝑖delimited-[]𝑚\mathcal{X}=\{\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{i},a_{i})\}_{i\in[m]}caligraphic_X = { roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Sisubscript𝑆𝑖S_{i}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT and aisubscript𝑎𝑖a_{i}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT are the i𝑖iitalic_i-th evaluated solution set and element. LinTG first begins by taking a single sample of the marginal gain of the current element of U𝑈Uitalic_U (Line 15). In a loop on Lines 21 to 32, LinTG iteratively identifies the best marginal gain vector to sample from the set 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X in order to decrease ‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,a)‖A−1subscriptnormΔF𝑆𝑎superscriptA1||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,a)||_{\textbf{A}^{-1}}| | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_a ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT as fast as possible. Notice that this is different from the strategy of LG since we are no longer attempting to distinguish the highest marginal gain from the rest, but only make a decision about a single marginal gain. Let pi∗superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the fraction of samples allocated to element Δ⁢F⁢(Si,ai)ΔFsubscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{i},a_{i})roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ), with ∑i∈[m]pi=1subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscript𝑝𝑖1\sum_{i\in[m]}p_{i}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1, which is asymptotically optimal for decreasing ‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,a)‖A−1subscriptnormΔF𝑆𝑎superscriptA1||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,a)||_{\textbf{A}^{-1}}| | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_a ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. pi∗superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖p_{i}^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT can be calculated by solving a linear programming problem (see Appendix for more details about how to calculate pi∗subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑖p^{*}_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT). Notice that there are a total of O⁢(nα⁢log⁡κα)𝑂𝑛𝛼𝜅𝛼O(\frac{n}{\alpha}\log\frac{\kappa}{\alpha})italic_O ( divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_α end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG italic_κ end_ARG start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ) number of evaluations of the marginal gains, and for each marginal gain, we only need to solve one linear programming problem. Thus LinTG only requires solving O⁢(nα⁢log⁡κα)𝑂𝑛𝛼𝜅𝛼O(\frac{n}{\alpha}\log\frac{\kappa}{\alpha})italic_O ( divide start_ARG italic_n end_ARG start_ARG italic_α end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG italic_κ end_ARG start_ARG italic_α end_ARG ) linear programming problems which decreases compared with LG. On the other hand, since we only consider one allocation ratio for each evaluated marginal gain, the greedy selection strategy in Line 22 can be changed to run in batches. Here βtsubscript𝛽𝑡\beta_{t}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes the confidence interval which is defined as βt=(R⁢2⁢log⁡2⁢det(At)12⁢det(λ⁢I)−12δ+λ12⁢S)⁢‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,a)‖At−1subscript𝛽𝑡𝑅22superscriptsubscriptA𝑡12superscript𝜆𝐼12𝛿superscript𝜆12𝑆subscriptnormΔF𝑆𝑎superscriptsubscriptA𝑡1\beta_{t}=\big{(}R\sqrt{2\log\frac{2\det(\textbf{A}_{t})^{\frac{1}{2}}\det(% \lambda I)^{-\frac{1}{2}}}{\delta}}+\lambda^{\frac{1}{2}}S\big{)}||\Delta% \textbf{F}(S,a)||_{\textbf{A}_{t}^{-1}}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_R square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log divide start_ARG 2 roman_det ( A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_det ( italic_λ italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG end_ARG + italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S ) | | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_a ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The theoretical guarantee of LinTG is in Theorem 3.

Each iterative sample is followed by an update of A,bAb\textbf{A},\textbf{b}A , b, and then the estimate w^^w\hat{\textbf{w}}over^ start_ARG w end_ARG are all updated according to the procedure described in Section 2.2 on Lines 29. Once it has been determined whether the marginal gain is above w𝑤witalic_w (Line 23) or not (Line 25), a𝑎aitalic_a is added or not respectively to S𝑆Sitalic_S and LinTG repeats the procedure with the next element of U𝑈Uitalic_U.

Theorem 3.

LinTG makes n⁢log⁡(κ/α)/αnκααn\log(\kappa/\alpha)/\alphaitalic_n roman_log ( italic_κ / italic_α ) / italic_α evaluations of the marginal gains. In addition, with probability at least 1−δ1δ1-\delta1 - italic_δ, the following statements hold:

  1. 1.

    The function value of the output solution set S𝑆Sitalic_S satisfies that f⁢(S)≥(1−e−1−α)⁢f⁢(O⁢P⁢T)−2⁢ϵ.𝑓𝑆1superscript𝑒1𝛼𝑓𝑂𝑃𝑇2italic-ϵf(S)\geq(1-e^{-1}-\alpha)f(OPT)-2\epsilon.italic_f ( italic_S ) ≥ ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_α ) italic_f ( italic_O italic_P italic_T ) - 2 italic_ϵ . Here O⁢P⁢T𝑂𝑃𝑇OPTitalic_O italic_P italic_T is an optimal solution to the SM problem;

  2. 2.

    Assuming λ≤2⁢R2S2⁢log⁡2δ𝜆2superscript𝑅2superscript𝑆22𝛿\lambda\leq\frac{2R^{2}}{S^{2}}\log\frac{2}{\delta}italic_λ ≤ divide start_ARG 2 italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG, the m𝑚mitalic_m-th evaluation of the marginal gain of adding an element a𝑎aitalic_a to S𝑆Sitalic_S in LinTG takes at most

    ∑i∈[m]max⁡{4⁢Hi(m)⁢R2⁢(2⁢log⁡2δ+d⁢log⁡M(m))+1−Ni(m),0}subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚4subscriptsuperscript𝐻𝑚𝑖superscript𝑅222𝛿𝑑superscript𝑀𝑚1superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑖𝑚0\displaystyle\sum_{i\in[m]}\max\{4H^{(m)}_{i}R^{2}(2\log\frac{2}{\delta}+d\log M% ^{(m)})+1-N_{i}^{(m)},0\}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max { 4 italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 roman_log divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG + italic_d roman_log italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + 1 - italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0 }

    samples, where M(m)=16⁢Hϵ(m)⁢R2⁢L2λ⁢log⁡2δ+32⁢(Hϵ(m))2⁢R4⁢L4λ2+2⁢(N(m)+m)⁢L2λ⁢d+2superscript𝑀𝑚16superscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑚superscript𝑅2superscript𝐿2𝜆2𝛿32superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑚2superscript𝑅4superscript𝐿4superscript𝜆22superscript𝑁𝑚𝑚superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑑2M^{(m)}=\frac{16H_{\epsilon}^{(m)}R^{2}L^{2}}{\lambda}\log\frac{2}{\delta}+% \frac{32(H_{\epsilon}^{(m)})^{2}R^{4}L^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}+\frac{2(N^{(m)}+m)L^{% 2}}{\lambda d}+2italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 16 italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG + divide start_ARG 32 ( italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_m ) italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG + 2. N(m)superscript𝑁𝑚N^{(m)}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the total number of samples before the m𝑚mitalic_m-th evaluation of marginal gains. Ni(m)subscriptsuperscript𝑁𝑚𝑖N^{(m)}_{i}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the number of samples to the marginal gain Δ⁢f⁢(Si,ai)Δ𝑓subscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖\Delta f(S_{i},a_{i})roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) before the m𝑚mitalic_m-th evaluation of marginal gains. ρ(m)superscript𝜌𝑚\rho^{(m)}italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the optimal vale of (14).

The result on the sample complexity can be derived directly by Theorem 6. The detailed proof of the approximation ratio is presented in Section B in the appendix. If we replace the allocation ratio p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with any other ratio p𝑝pitalic_p, the result in the theorem would still hold, with the value of ρ(m)superscript𝜌𝑚\rho^{(m)}italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT being replaced by ‖Δ⁢F⁢(Sm,am)‖Λ−12subscriptsuperscriptnormΔFsubscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚2superscriptΛ1||\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{m},a_{m})||^{2}_{\Lambda^{-1}}| | roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT where Λ=∑i∈[m]pi∗⁢Δ⁢F⁢(Si,ai)⁢Δ⁢F⁢(Si,ai)TΛsubscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑝𝑖ΔFsubscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖ΔFsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖𝑇\Lambda=\sum_{i\in[m]}p_{i}^{*}\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{i},a_{i})\Delta\textbf{F}(S% _{i},a_{i})^{T}roman_Λ = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT.

5 Experiments

In this section, we conduct experiments on the instance of movie recommendation. The dataset used in the experiments are subsets extracted from the MovieLens 25M dataset Harper and Konstan (2015), which comprises 162,541162541162,541162 , 541 ratings for 13,8161381613,81613 , 816 movies, each associated with 1,12811281,1281 , 128 topics. We compare the sample complexity of different algorithms with different values of size constraint κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ, error parameter ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ, and different datasets with different values of d𝑑ditalic_d. When κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ is varied, ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ is fixed at 0.10.10.10.1. The dataset movie60 contains 60606060 elements with d=5𝑑5d=5italic_d = 5, |V|=500𝑉500|V|=500| italic_V | = 500. The dataset movie5000 contains n=5000𝑛5000n=5000italic_n = 5000 elements with d=30𝑑30d=30italic_d = 30, |V|=1000𝑉1000|V|=1000| italic_V | = 1000. For the algorithms comparing different values of d𝑑ditalic_d, we run the algorithms on different datasets with different values of d𝑑ditalic_d. Here n𝑛nitalic_n and |V|𝑉|V|| italic_V | are fixed at 500500500500. Additional details about the applications, setup, and results can be found in Section C in the supplementary material.

In the application of movie recommendation, the submodular basis function Fisubscript𝐹𝑖F_{i}italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT denotes how well a subset movies the topic i𝑖iitalic_i, which is defined by the probabilistic movieage model as is presented in the appendix. The noisy marginal gain is sampled in the following way: first we uniformly sample a user atsubscript𝑎𝑡a_{t}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT from the set of users V𝑉Vitalic_V, then the noisy marginal gain of adding a new movie x𝑥xitalic_x into a subset S𝑆Sitalic_S is Δ⁢ft⁢(S,x)=∑i∈[d]w⁢(at,i)⁢Δ⁢Fi⁢(S,x)=w⁢(at,⋅)T⁢Δ⁢F⁢(S,x)Δsubscript𝑓𝑡𝑆𝑥subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑑𝑤subscript𝑎𝑡𝑖Δsubscript𝐹𝑖𝑆𝑥wsuperscriptsubscript𝑎𝑡⋅𝑇ΔF𝑆𝑥\Delta f_{t}(S,x)=\sum_{i\in[d]}w(a_{t},i)\Delta F_{i}(S,x)=\textbf{w}(a_{t},% \cdot)^{T}\Delta\textbf{F}(S,x)roman_Δ italic_f start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_d ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_w ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i ) roman_Δ italic_F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ) = w ( italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ⋅ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_x ). Consequently, the exact value of our submodular objective is the average of marginal gain for all elements, i.e., Δ⁢f⁢(S,x)=1|V|⁢∑a∈Vw⁢(a,⋅)T⁢Δ⁢F⁢(S,x)Δ𝑓𝑆𝑥1𝑉subscript𝑎𝑉wsuperscript𝑎⋅𝑇ΔF𝑆𝑥\Delta f(S,x)=\frac{1}{|V|}\sum_{a\in V}\textbf{w}(a,\cdot)^{T}\Delta\textbf{F% }(S,x)roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_x ) = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | italic_V | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT w ( italic_a , ⋅ ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_x ). Denote the average weight vector w¯¯w\bar{\textbf{w}}over¯ start_ARG w end_ARG as w¯=1|V|⁢∑a∈Vw⁢(a,⋅)¯w1𝑉subscript𝑎𝑉w𝑎⋅\bar{\textbf{w}}=\frac{1}{|V|}\sum_{a\in V}\textbf{w}(a,\cdot)over¯ start_ARG w end_ARG = divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG | italic_V | end_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ italic_V end_POSTSUBSCRIPT w ( italic_a , ⋅ ), then it follows that Δ⁢f⁢(S,x)=w¯T⁢Δ⁢F⁢(S,x)Δ𝑓𝑆𝑥superscript¯w𝑇ΔF𝑆𝑥\Delta f(S,x)=\bar{\textbf{w}}^{T}\Delta\textbf{F}(S,x)roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_x ) = over¯ start_ARG w end_ARG start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_x ).

We compare the solutions returned by the following five algorithms: (i). The algorithm LG (”Lin-GREEDY”). Due to the high computational cost, here we don’t solve the linear programming problems and replace the asymptotic optimal allocation ratio p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT with the allocation p𝑝pitalic_p that satisfies p⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)=0.5𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗0.5p(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)=0.5italic_p ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) = 0.5 if a𝑎aitalic_a is i𝑖iitalic_i or j𝑗jitalic_j and l′=lsuperscript𝑙′𝑙l^{\prime}=litalic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_l. Otherwise p⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)=0𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗0p(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)=0italic_p ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) = 0 (see Section A.2.1 for more details.) ; (ii). The linear greedy algorithm LinTG. Here we consider two choices of the allocation parameters. The first one satisfies that pm=1subscript𝑝𝑚1p_{m}=1italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1 and pa=0subscript𝑝𝑎0p_{a}=0italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 0 for a≠m𝑎𝑚a\neq mitalic_a ≠ italic_m, i.e., the algorithm only samples the current marginal gain (”LinTG-H”). The second one is pa=|wa∗|∑a∈[m]|wa∗|subscript𝑝𝑎superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎subscript𝑎delimited-[]𝑚superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎p_{a}=\frac{|w_{a}^{*}|}{\sum_{a\in[m]}|w_{a}^{*}|}italic_p start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG | italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | end_ARG where wa∗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑎w_{a}^{*}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the optimal solution of the linear programming problem defined in the algorithm description (”LinTG”); (iii). The ExpGreedy algorithm from Singla et al. (2016) with the parameter k′superscript𝑘′k^{\prime}italic_k start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT set to be 1111 (”Exp-GREEDY”); (iv). The threshold-greedy algorithm without considering the linear structure (”TG”). More details about the algorithms can be found in the appendix.

We present the results in terms of the number of evaluations in Figure 1. Due to the high sample complexity and heavy computational burden resulting from solving the linear programming problem, here we only run the algorithms EXP-GREEDY, LinGREEDY, and LinTG on the relatively small dataset movie60. From the results on the dataset movie60, we can see that the sample complexity of the algorithms that don’t consider the linear structure (EXP-GREEDY and TG) is much higher than the algorithms proposed in this paper, which demonstrates the advantages of our proposed methods. In particular, the algorithms LinTG and LinTG-H have the lowest sample complexity compared with other methods. Besides, we notice that the algorithm when ϵitalic-ϵ\epsilonitalic_ϵ is very small, the algorithms TG has an increase on the sample complexity. From Figure 1(d), we can see the sample complexity of the algorithm LinTG-H increases as d𝑑ditalic_d increases, which is consistent with our theoretical results on sample complexity.
