Appendix

Appendix A Appendix for Section 3

In this portion of the appendix, we present missing details and proofs from Section 3 in the main paper. We first present Lemma 1, which guarantees that for any standard greedy-based algorithm which satisfies that the element added at each round has the highest marginal gain within an ϵ/κitalic-ϵ𝜅\epsilon/\kappaitalic_ϵ / italic_κ-additive error, then the ultimate solution set satisfies that f⁢(S)≥(1−e−1)⁢f⁢(O⁢P⁢T)−ϵ𝑓𝑆1superscript𝑒1𝑓𝑂𝑃𝑇italic-ϵf(S)\geq(1-e^{-1})f(OPT)-\epsilonitalic_f ( italic_S ) ≥ ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_O italic_P italic_T ) - italic_ϵ. Then we propose and analyze the static allocation strategy LBSS in Section A.1. The pseudocode of LBSS is presented in Algorithm 3 in Section A.1. Finally, we present the missing proofs and details about the theoretical guarantee of LG from Section 3 in Section A.2. Lemma 1 is given as follows.

Lemma 1.

For any standard greedy-based algorithm proposed for our problem, if with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, the element a𝑎aitalic_a added to the solution set S𝑆Sitalic_S at each round satisfies that Δ⁢f⁢(S,a)≥maxs∈U⁡Δ⁢f⁢(S,s)−ϵ/κΔ𝑓𝑆𝑎subscript𝑠𝑈Δ𝑓𝑆𝑠italic-ϵ𝜅\Delta f(S,a)\geq\max_{s\in U}\Delta f(S,s)-\epsilon/\kapparoman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_a ) ≥ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_s ∈ italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ italic_f ( italic_S , italic_s ) - italic_ϵ / italic_κ, then it follows that the output solution set S𝑆Sitalic_S satisfies that with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ

f⁢(S)≥(1−e−1)⁢f⁢(O⁢P⁢T)−ϵ.𝑓𝑆1superscript𝑒1𝑓𝑂𝑃𝑇italic-ϵ\displaystyle f(S)\geq(1-e^{-1})f(OPT)-\epsilon.italic_f ( italic_S ) ≥ ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_O italic_P italic_T ) - italic_ϵ .
Proof.

The proof of this lemma is similar to the standard greedy algorithm and can be derived from the proof of ExpGreedy in Singla et al. [2016], so we omit the proof here. ∎

A.1 Warm-up: static allocation strategy

In this section, we present the warm-up algorithm LBSS, which combines the standard greedy algorithm with a subroutine inspired by the static allocation proposed in best-arm identification problem in linear bandit Soare et al. [2014]. The strategy is static in that the sequence of sampled feature vectors xatsubscriptxsubscript𝑎𝑡\textbf{x}_{a_{t}}x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is independent from the sampling results. However, unlike the static allocation algorithm proposed in Soare et al. [2014], which finds the exact optimal solution, here in LBSS, the algorithm finds the element with the highest marginal gain within an ϵ/κitalic-ϵ𝜅\epsilon/\kappaitalic_ϵ / italic_κ additive error. The theoretical guarantee is stated below. In particular, we first give a description of the static strategy. Next, we provide the detailed statement and proofs of Theorem 4.

The algorithm proceeds in rounds. In each round, the algorithm selects the element with the highest marginal gain by taking noisy samples of the marginal gains of adding new elements to the current solution set. For notation simplicity, in the following part, we use FxsubscriptF𝑥\textbf{F}_{x}F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to denote the marginal gain of adding element x𝑥xitalic_x to the solution set in the current round S𝑆Sitalic_S. i.e., Fx=Δ⁢F⁢(S,x)subscriptF𝑥ΔF𝑆𝑥\textbf{F}_{x}=\Delta\textbf{F}(S,x)F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_x ). The sampled element is chosen in a greedy manner to make maxx,x′∈U⁢‖Fx−Fx′‖At−1subscript𝑥superscript𝑥′𝑈subscriptnormsubscriptF𝑥subscriptFsuperscript𝑥′superscriptsubscriptA𝑡1\max_{x,x^{\prime}\in U}||\textbf{F}_{x}-\textbf{F}_{x^{\prime}}||_{\textbf{A}% _{t}^{-1}}roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_U end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to decrease as fast as possible. It is worthy to note that in LBSS, the update of parameters w^tsubscript^w𝑡\hat{\textbf{w}}_{t}over^ start_ARG w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is calculated based on the least-square estimator. Therefore, At+1=At+xat⁢xatTsubscriptA𝑡1subscriptA𝑡subscriptxsubscript𝑎𝑡superscriptsubscriptxsubscript𝑎𝑡𝑇\textbf{A}_{t+1}=\textbf{A}_{t}+\textbf{x}_{a_{t}}\textbf{x}_{a_{t}}^{T}A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, bt+1=bt+rt⁢xatsubscriptb𝑡1subscriptb𝑡subscript𝑟𝑡subscriptxsubscript𝑎𝑡\textbf{b}_{t+1}=\textbf{b}_{t}+r_{t}\textbf{x}_{a_{t}}b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_r start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT x start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, and that w^t+1=At+1−1⁢bt+1subscript^w𝑡1subscriptsuperscriptA1𝑡1subscriptb𝑡1\hat{\textbf{w}}_{t+1}=\textbf{A}^{-1}_{t+1}\textbf{b}_{t+1}over^ start_ARG w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = A start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT b start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t + 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. The parameter Dtsubscript𝐷𝑡D_{t}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is defined as Dt=R⁢2⁢log⁡(π2⁢t2⁢κ⁢n23⁢δ)subscript𝐷𝑡𝑅2superscript𝜋2superscript𝑡2𝜅superscript𝑛23𝛿D_{t}=R\sqrt{2\log(\frac{\pi^{2}t^{2}\kappa n^{2}}{3\delta})}italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_R square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log ( divide start_ARG italic_π start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_t start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_κ italic_n start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 3 italic_δ end_ARG ) end_ARG.

A.1.1 proof of Theorem 4

We now present the missing theoretical proofs for Theorem 4, where we provide bounds on the expectation of the reward of the output element and the sample complexity of LBSS in Algorithm 3.

Theorem 4.

With probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, the following statements hold:

  1. 1.

    The exact function value of the output solution set S𝑆Sitalic_S satisfies that f⁢(S)≥(1−e−1)⁢f⁢(O⁢P⁢T)−ϵ.𝑓𝑆1superscript𝑒1𝑓𝑂𝑃𝑇italic-ϵf(S)\geq(1-e^{-1})f(OPT)-\epsilon.italic_f ( italic_S ) ≥ ( 1 - italic_e start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_f ( italic_O italic_P italic_T ) - italic_ϵ . Here O⁢P⁢T𝑂𝑃𝑇OPTitalic_O italic_P italic_T is an optimal solution to the SM problem;

  2. 2.

    During each round in LBSS, the number of samples required is upper bounded by

    t≤max⁡{256⁢R2⁢dmax⁡{Δmin2,ϵ2/κ2}⁢log⁡(256⁢R2⁢d⁢π⁢nmax⁡{Δmin2,ϵ2/κ2}⁢κ3⁢δ),d+d2+22}𝑡256superscript𝑅2𝑑superscriptsubscriptΔ2superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝜅2256superscript𝑅2𝑑𝜋𝑛superscriptsubscriptΔ2superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝜅2𝜅3𝛿𝑑superscript𝑑222t\leq\max\{\frac{256R^{2}d}{\max\{\Delta_{\min}^{2},\epsilon^{2}/\kappa^{2}\}}% \log(\frac{256R^{2}d\pi n}{\max\{\Delta_{\min}^{2},\epsilon^{2}/\kappa^{2}\}}% \sqrt{\frac{\kappa}{3\delta}}),\frac{d+d^{2}+2}{2}\}italic_t ≤ roman_max { divide start_ARG 256 italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_ARG start_ARG roman_max { roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_κ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 256 italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_π italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_max { roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_κ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_κ end_ARG start_ARG 3 italic_δ end_ARG end_ARG ) , divide start_ARG italic_d + italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG }

    where Δmin=min{x′∈[n],x′≠x∗}⁡Fx∗T⁢w−Fx′T⁢wsubscriptΔsubscriptformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑥′delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝑥′superscript𝑥superscriptsubscriptFsuperscript𝑥𝑇wsuperscriptsubscriptFsuperscript𝑥′𝑇w\Delta_{\min}=\min_{\{x^{\prime}\in[n],x^{\prime}\neq x^{*}\}}\textbf{F}_{x^{*% }}^{T}\textbf{w}-\textbf{F}_{x^{\prime}}^{T}\textbf{w}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_n ] , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w - F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w and x∗=arg⁡maxx∈[n]⁡FxT⁢wsuperscript𝑥subscript𝑥delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscriptF𝑥𝑇wx^{*}=\arg\max_{x\in[n]}\textbf{F}_{x}^{T}\textbf{w}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w.

From Lemma 1, we can see that the theorem can be proved immediately by Lemma 2, which is presented below.

Lemma 2.

With probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, in each round of the Algorithm 3, the selected element x𝑥xitalic_x satisfies

FxT⁢w≥Fx∗T⁢w−ϵ/κ.subscriptsuperscriptF𝑇𝑥wsubscriptsuperscriptF𝑇superscript𝑥witalic-ϵ𝜅\displaystyle\textbf{F}^{T}_{x}\textbf{w}\geq\textbf{F}^{T}_{x^{*}}\textbf{w}-% \epsilon/\kappa.F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT w ≥ F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT w - italic_ϵ / italic_κ . (1)

Besides, the number of samples required by each round is upper bounded by

t≤max⁡{256⁢R2⁢dmax⁡{Δmin2,ϵ2/κ2}⁢log⁡(256⁢R2⁢d⁢π⁢nmax⁡{Δmin2,ϵ2/κ2}⁢κ3⁢δ),d+d2+22}𝑡256superscript𝑅2𝑑superscriptsubscriptΔ2superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝜅2256superscript𝑅2𝑑𝜋𝑛superscriptsubscriptΔ2superscriptitalic-ϵ2superscript𝜅2𝜅3𝛿𝑑superscript𝑑222t\leq\max\{\frac{256R^{2}d}{\max\{\Delta_{\min}^{2},\epsilon^{2}/\kappa^{2}\}}% \log(\frac{256R^{2}d\pi n}{\max\{\Delta_{\min}^{2},\epsilon^{2}/\kappa^{2}\}}% \sqrt{\frac{\kappa}{3\delta}}),\frac{d+d^{2}+2}{2}\}italic_t ≤ roman_max { divide start_ARG 256 italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d end_ARG start_ARG roman_max { roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_κ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 256 italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_d italic_π italic_n end_ARG start_ARG roman_max { roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT / italic_κ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } end_ARG square-root start_ARG divide start_ARG italic_κ end_ARG start_ARG 3 italic_δ end_ARG end_ARG ) , divide start_ARG italic_d + italic_d start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 2 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG }

where Δmin=min{x′∈[n],x′≠x∗}⁡Fx∗T⁢w−Fx′T⁢wsubscriptΔsubscriptformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑥′delimited-[]𝑛superscript𝑥′superscript𝑥superscriptsubscriptFsuperscript𝑥𝑇wsuperscriptsubscriptFsuperscript𝑥′𝑇w\Delta_{\min}=\min_{\{x^{\prime}\in[n],x^{\prime}\neq x^{*}\}}\textbf{F}_{x^{*% }}^{T}\textbf{w}-\textbf{F}_{x^{\prime}}^{T}\textbf{w}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_min end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_n ] , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ≠ italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w - F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w, and x∗=arg⁡maxx′∈[n]⁡Fx′T⁢wsuperscript𝑥subscriptsuperscript𝑥′delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscriptFsuperscript𝑥′𝑇wx^{*}=\arg\max_{x^{\prime}\in[n]}\textbf{F}_{x^{\prime}}^{T}\textbf{w}italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w.

Next, we present the proof of Lemma 2.

Proof.

Our argument to prove Lemma 2 follows a similar approach as Soare et al. [2014]. First, we provide proof of (1) on the expectation of the reward of the returned element. Notice that by Proposition 5, and by applying a union bound over all κ𝜅\kappaitalic_κ rounds, with probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, we have that for each round l𝑙litalic_l, and for any x,x′∈U𝑥superscript𝑥′𝑈x,x^{\prime}\in Uitalic_x , italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_U,

|(Fx′−Fx)T⁢(w−w^t)|≤‖Fx′−Fx‖At−1⁢Dt.superscriptsubscriptFsuperscript𝑥′subscriptF𝑥𝑇wsubscript^w𝑡subscriptnormsubscriptFsuperscript𝑥′subscriptF𝑥superscriptsubscriptA𝑡1subscript𝐷𝑡\displaystyle|(\textbf{F}_{x^{\prime}}-\textbf{F}_{x})^{T}(\textbf{w}-\hat{% \textbf{w}}_{t})|\leq||\textbf{F}_{x^{\prime}}-\textbf{F}_{x}||_{\textbf{A}_{t% }^{-1}}D_{t}.| ( F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( w - over^ start_ARG w end_ARG start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | ≤ | | F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT - F start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_D start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT . (2)

From the stopping condition of the algorithm, we know that when the algorithm stops, there exists an element x such that ∀x′∈Ufor-allsuperscriptx′𝑈\forall\textbf{x}^{\prime}\in U∀ x start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ italic_U

From Lemma 14, we conclude that

∎

A.2 Additional Content to Section 3

In this appendix, we present the missing content in Section 3. First, we provide a detailed discussion on the sampling allocation ratio p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT used in LG in Section A.2.1. Next, we delve into the proof of Theorem 2, which provides the theoretical guarantee concerning the algorithm LG.

A.2.1 Discussion on the sample allocation ratio

In our algorithm LG, we use the allocation ratio p∗⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)superscript𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ). p∗⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)superscript𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) is the asymptotic-optimal ratio of sampling Δ⁢F⁢(Sl′,a)ΔFsubscript𝑆superscript𝑙′𝑎\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{l^{\prime}},a)roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a ), which is the marginal gain of adding element a𝑎aitalic_a to set Sl′subscript𝑆superscript𝑙′S_{l^{\prime}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT for decreasing the confidence interval ‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)‖At−1subscriptnormΔF𝑆𝑖ΔF𝑆𝑗superscriptsubscriptA𝑡1||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)||_{\textbf{A}_{t}^{-1}}| | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT when the number of samples goes to infinity at the round l𝑙litalic_l. By Lemma 13, it satisfies that

p∗⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)=|wl′,a∗⁢(i,j)|∑l′′=1l∑a′=1n|wl′′,a′∗⁢(i,j)|,superscript𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗subscriptsuperscript𝑤superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑖𝑗superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑙′′1𝑙superscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑎′1𝑛subscriptsuperscript𝑤superscript𝑙′′superscript𝑎′𝑖𝑗\displaystyle p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)=\frac{|w^{*}_{l^{\prime},a}(i,j)|}{% \sum_{l^{\prime\prime}=1}^{l}\sum_{a^{\prime}=1}^{n}|w^{*}_{l^{\prime\prime},a% ^{\prime}}(i,j)|},italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) = divide start_ARG | italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) | end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) | end_ARG , (4)

where {wl′,a∗⁢(i,j)}a∈[n]subscriptsubscriptsuperscript𝑤superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑖𝑗𝑎delimited-[]𝑛\{w^{*}_{l^{\prime},a}(i,j)\}_{a\in[n]}{ italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) } start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the optimal solution of the linear program in (5) below

argmin{wl′,a⁢(i,j)}∑l′=1l∑a=1n|wl′,a(i,j)|s.t.ΔF(S,i)−ΔF(S,j)=∑l′=1l∑a=1nwl′,a(i,j)ΔF(Sl′,a).\displaystyle\arg\min_{\{w_{l^{\prime},a}(i,j)\}}\sum_{l^{\prime}=1}^{l}\sum_{% a=1}^{n}|w_{l^{\prime},a}(i,j)|\qquad s.t.\qquad\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta% \textbf{F}(S,j)=\sum_{l^{\prime}=1}^{l}\sum_{a=1}^{n}w_{l^{\prime},a}(i,j)% \Delta\textbf{F}(S_{l^{\prime}},a).roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT | italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) | italic_s . italic_t . roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_n end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a ) . (5)

Besides, as is illustrated in Section 3 and in the proof of Theorem 2 in Section A.2.2, if we replace the asymptotic allocation ratio p∗⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)superscript𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) with any allocation policy p⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗p(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)italic_p ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ), we can still obtain a theoretical guarantee on the upper bound of the sample complexity for our algorithm LG. In particular, by setting the allocation ratio to p⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)=0.5𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗0.5p(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)=0.5italic_p ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) = 0.5 for l′=lsuperscript𝑙′𝑙l^{\prime}=litalic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_l and a=i𝑎𝑖a=iitalic_a = italic_i or j𝑗jitalic_j, and p⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)=0𝑝superscript𝑙′conditional𝑎𝑙𝑖𝑗0p(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)=0italic_p ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) = 0 otherwise, the allocation strategy in LG is similar to that used in the CLUCB algorithm in Chen et al. [2014]. Both these two algorithms sample the direction between Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)ΔF𝑆𝑖\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) and Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)ΔF𝑆𝑗\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) to decrease ‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)‖At−1subscriptnormΔF𝑆𝑖ΔF𝑆𝑗superscriptsubscriptA𝑡1||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)||_{\textbf{A}_{t}^{-1}}| | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Although this allocation ratio is not asymptotically optimal and follows a similar principle to the CLUCB algorithm, there are notable differences: (i) Our algorithm LG leverages the linear structure, and the concentration inequality used is derived from the linear bandit literature. (ii). The linear submodular bandit algorithm allows us to exploit sampling results from past greedy rounds while in the CLUCB algorithm developed for the general bandit setting, we are not allowed to do that. In our experiments, we also adopt this allocation ratio.

A.2.2 Proof of Theorem 2

In this section, we prove Theorem 2, which guarantees the sample complexity and approximation ratio of LG. From Lemma 1, we can see that proving Theorem 2 is equivalent to proving the following result.

Lemma 3.

With probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, in each round of the LG in Algorithm 1, the selected element a𝑎aitalic_a satisfies

ΔFT(S,a)w≥maxx∈[n]ΔFT(S,x))w−ϵ/κ\displaystyle\Delta\textbf{F}^{T}(S,a)\textbf{w}\geq\max_{x\in[n]}\Delta% \textbf{F}^{T}(S,x))\textbf{w}-\epsilon/\kapparoman_Δ F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_a ) w ≥ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ F start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_S , italic_x ) ) w - italic_ϵ / italic_κ

Besides, assume λ≤2⁢R2S2⁢log⁡1δ𝜆2superscript𝑅2superscript𝑆21𝛿\lambda\leq\frac{2R^{2}}{S^{2}}\log\frac{1}{\delta}italic_λ ≤ divide start_ARG 2 italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG, then during the round l𝑙litalic_l, the total number of samples τ𝜏\tauitalic_τ satisfies

τ𝜏\displaystyle\tauitalic_τ ≤∑l′∈[l],a∈[n]max⁡{4⁢Hl′,a(l)⁢R2⁢(2⁢log⁡1δ+d⁢log⁡M(l))+1−Nl′,a(l),0},absentsubscriptformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑙′delimited-[]𝑙𝑎delimited-[]𝑛4subscriptsuperscript𝐻𝑙superscript𝑙′𝑎superscript𝑅221𝛿𝑑superscript𝑀𝑙1superscriptsubscript𝑁superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙0\displaystyle\leq\sum_{l^{\prime}\in[l],a\in[n]}\max\{4H^{(l)}_{l^{\prime},a}R% ^{2}(2\log\frac{1}{\delta}+d\log M^{(l)})+1-N_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)},0\},≤ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_l ] , italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max { 4 italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG + italic_d roman_log italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + 1 - italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0 } ,

where M(l)=16⁢Hϵ(l)⁢R2⁢L2λ⁢log⁡(1δ)+32⁢(Hϵ(l))2⁢R4⁢L4λ2+2⁢(N(l)+n⁢l)⁢L2λ⁢d+2superscript𝑀𝑙16superscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑙superscript𝑅2superscript𝐿2𝜆1𝛿32superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑙2superscript𝑅4superscript𝐿4superscript𝜆22superscript𝑁𝑙𝑛𝑙superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑑2M^{(l)}=\frac{16H_{\epsilon}^{(l)}R^{2}L^{2}}{\lambda}\log(\frac{1}{\delta})+% \frac{32(H_{\epsilon}^{(l)})^{2}R^{4}L^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}+\frac{2(N^{(l)}+nl)L^% {2}}{\lambda d}+2italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 16 italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG roman_log ( divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG ) + divide start_ARG 32 ( italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_n italic_l ) italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG + 2. Proof.

Throughout the proof, we assume the clean event ℰℰ\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E occurs. The event ℰℰ\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E is defined as

ℰ={∀t>0,∀i,j∈[n],|(Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j))T⁢(w^−w)|≤βt⁢(i,j)},ℰformulae-sequencefor-all𝑡0for-all𝑖formulae-sequence𝑗delimited-[]𝑛superscriptΔF𝑆𝑖ΔF𝑆𝑗𝑇^wwsubscript𝛽𝑡𝑖𝑗\displaystyle\mathcal{E}=\{\forall t>0,\forall i,j\in[n],|(\Delta\textbf{F}(S,% i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j))^{T}(\hat{\textbf{w}}-\textbf{w})|\leq\beta_{t}(i,j)\},caligraphic_E = { ∀ italic_t > 0 , ∀ italic_i , italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] , | ( roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG w end_ARG - w ) | ≤ italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) } ,

where the confidence interval βt⁢(i,j)=Ct⁢‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)‖At−1subscript𝛽𝑡𝑖𝑗subscript𝐶𝑡superscriptsubscriptnormΔF𝑆𝑖ΔF𝑆𝑗subscriptA𝑡1\beta_{t}(i,j)=C_{t}||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)||_{\textbf{A% }_{t}}^{-1}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i , italic_j ) = italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT and that Ct=R⁢2⁢log⁡det(At)12⁢det(λ⁢I)−12δ+λ12⁢Ssubscript𝐶𝑡𝑅2superscriptsubscriptA𝑡12superscript𝜆𝐼12𝛿superscript𝜆12𝑆C_{t}=R\sqrt{2\log\frac{\det(\textbf{A}_{t})^{\frac{1}{2}}\det(\lambda I)^{-% \frac{1}{2}}}{\delta}}+\lambda^{\frac{1}{2}}Sitalic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_R square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log divide start_ARG roman_det ( A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_det ( italic_λ italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG end_ARG + italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S. Then by Proposition 1, and the fact that for all i𝑖iitalic_i, Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)ΔF𝑆𝑖\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) only depends on the past samples of marginal gains, we have the following lemma.

Lemma 4.

With probability at least 1−δ1𝛿1-\delta1 - italic_δ, event ℰℰ\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E holds.

First of all, we prove the result on the correctness of the output element itsubscript𝑖𝑡i_{t}italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. Let us denote that a∗=arg⁡maxa∈[n]⁡Δ⁢F⁢(S,a)T⁢wsuperscript𝑎subscript𝑎delimited-[]𝑛ΔFsuperscript𝑆𝑎𝑇wa^{*}=\arg\max_{a\in[n]}\Delta\textbf{F}(S,a)^{T}\textbf{w}italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_arg roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_a ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w, and that ϵ′=ϵ/κsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′italic-ϵ𝜅\epsilon^{\prime}=\epsilon/\kappaitalic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_ϵ / italic_κ. By the stopping condition in LG, we have that

B⁢(t)=(Δ⁢F⁢(S,jt)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,it))T⁢w^+βt⁢(it,jt)≤ϵ′.𝐵𝑡superscriptΔF𝑆subscript𝑗𝑡ΔF𝑆subscript𝑖𝑡𝑇^wsubscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝑖𝑡subscript𝑗𝑡superscriptitalic-ϵ′\displaystyle B(t)=(\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j_{t})-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i_{t}))^{T}% \hat{\textbf{w}}+\beta_{t}(i_{t},j_{t})\leq\epsilon^{\prime}.italic_B ( italic_t ) = ( roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG w end_ARG + italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

By the selection strategy of jtsubscript𝑗𝑡j_{t}italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT, we have that B⁢(t)≥(Δ⁢F⁢(S,a∗)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,it))T⁢w^+βt⁢(a∗,it)T𝐵𝑡superscriptΔF𝑆superscript𝑎ΔF𝑆subscript𝑖𝑡𝑇^wsubscript𝛽𝑡superscriptsuperscript𝑎subscript𝑖𝑡𝑇B(t)\geq(\Delta\textbf{F}(S,a^{*})-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i_{t}))^{T}\hat{\textbf{% w}}+\beta_{t}(a^{*},i_{t})^{T}italic_B ( italic_t ) ≥ ( roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG w end_ARG + italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Therefore, by Lemma 4, we have that

(Δ⁢F⁢(S,a∗)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,it))T⁢w≤(Δ⁢F⁢(S,a∗)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,it))T⁢w^+βt⁢(a∗,it)≤ϵ′.superscriptΔF𝑆superscript𝑎ΔF𝑆subscript𝑖𝑡𝑇wsuperscriptΔF𝑆superscript𝑎ΔF𝑆subscript𝑖𝑡𝑇^wsubscript𝛽𝑡superscript𝑎subscript𝑖𝑡superscriptitalic-ϵ′\displaystyle(\Delta\textbf{F}(S,a^{*})-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i_{t}))^{T}\textbf{% w}\leq(\Delta\textbf{F}(S,a^{*})-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i_{t}))^{T}\hat{\textbf{w}% }+\beta_{t}(a^{*},i_{t})\leq\epsilon^{\prime}.( roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w ≤ ( roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT over^ start_ARG w end_ARG + italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

Next, we prove the theoretical guarantee of the sample complexity. Let us denote Δl,isubscriptΔ𝑙𝑖\Delta_{l,i}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to be the gap between element i𝑖iitalic_i and the element with the highest marginal gain at round l𝑙litalic_l, i.e., Δl,i=maxx∈[n]⁡Δ⁢F⁢(Sl,x)T⁢w−Δ⁢F⁢(Sl,i)T⁢wsubscriptΔ𝑙𝑖subscript𝑥delimited-[]𝑛ΔFsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑙𝑥𝑇wΔFsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑙𝑖𝑇w\Delta_{l,i}=\max_{x\in[n]}\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{l},x)^{T}\textbf{w}-\Delta% \textbf{F}(S_{l},i)^{T}\textbf{w}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w - roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_i ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w. At the round l𝑙litalic_l, we have that the solution set S=Sl𝑆subscript𝑆𝑙S=S_{l}italic_S = italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. For notation simplicity, we denote Δi=maxx∈[n]⁡Δ⁢F⁢(S,x)T⁢w−Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)T⁢wsubscriptΔ𝑖subscript𝑥delimited-[]𝑛ΔFsuperscript𝑆𝑥𝑇wΔFsuperscript𝑆𝑖𝑇w\Delta_{i}=\max_{x\in[n]}\Delta\textbf{F}(S,x)^{T}\textbf{w}-\Delta\textbf{F}(% S,i)^{T}\textbf{w}roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_x ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_x ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w. From Lemma 4 in the appendix of Xu et al. [2018], we have

Lemma 5.

Under event ℰℰ\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E, throughout the execution of LG, B⁢(t)𝐵𝑡B(t)italic_B ( italic_t ) can be bounded as

B⁢(t)≤min⁡(0,−(Δit∨Δjt)+2⁢βt⁢(it,jt))+βt⁢(it,jt).𝐵𝑡0subscriptΔsubscript𝑖𝑡subscriptΔsubscript𝑗𝑡2subscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝑖𝑡subscript𝑗𝑡subscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝑖𝑡subscript𝑗𝑡\displaystyle B(t)\leq\min(0,-(\Delta_{i_{t}}\vee\Delta_{j_{t}})+2\beta_{t}(i_% {t},j_{t}))+\beta_{t}(i_{t},j_{t}).italic_B ( italic_t ) ≤ roman_min ( 0 , - ( roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) + 2 italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ) + italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) .

The proof is the same as in Xu et al. [2018], so we omit the proof here. First of all, we derive the bound on the total number of samples for each element a𝑎aitalic_a from the sampling set 𝒳𝒳\mathcal{X}caligraphic_X. Then by Lemma 5 and that B⁢(t)≥ϵ′𝐵𝑡superscriptitalic-ϵ′B(t)\geq\epsilon^{\prime}italic_B ( italic_t ) ≥ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT we have that

βt⁢(it,jt)≥max⁡{ϵ′,Δit∨Δjt+ϵ′3}.subscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝑖𝑡subscript𝑗𝑡superscriptitalic-ϵ′subscriptΔsubscript𝑖𝑡subscriptΔsubscript𝑗𝑡superscriptitalic-ϵ′3\displaystyle\beta_{t}(i_{t},j_{t})\geq\max\{\epsilon^{\prime},\frac{\Delta_{i% _{t}}\vee\Delta_{j_{t}}+\epsilon^{\prime}}{3}\}.italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) ≥ roman_max { italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , divide start_ARG roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } .

Suppose the marginal gain of adding an element a𝑎aitalic_a to subset Sl′subscript𝑆superscript𝑙′S_{l^{\prime}}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is sampled at time t𝑡titalic_t, from the element selection strategy, we have that for any other past marginal gain vectors, it follows that for any l′′∈[l]superscript𝑙′′delimited-[]𝑙l^{\prime\prime}\in[l]italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_l ] and a′∈[n]superscript𝑎′delimited-[]𝑛a^{\prime}\in[n]italic_a start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_n ],

Combine (6) with the above inequality, it follows that

where we define

Therefore, we have

Tl′,a⁢(t)≤p∗⁢(l′,a|l,it,jt)⁢‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,it)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,jt)‖Λit,jt−12⁢Ct2max{ϵ′,Δit∨Δjt+ϵ′3}2\displaystyle T_{l^{\prime},a}(t)\leq\frac{p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i_{t},j_{t})||% \Delta\textbf{F}(S,i_{t})-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j_{t})||^{2}_{\Lambda_{i_{t},j_{t% }}^{-1}}C_{t}^{2}}{\max\{\epsilon^{\prime},\frac{\Delta_{i_{t}}\vee\Delta_{j_{% t}}+\epsilon^{\prime}}{3}\}^{2}}italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_t ) ≤ divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_max { italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , divide start_ARG roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG
≤maxi,j∈[n]⁡p∗⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)⁢‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)‖Λi,j−12⁢Ct2max{ϵ′,Δi∨Δj+ϵ′3}2\displaystyle\leq\max_{i,j\in[n]}\frac{p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)||\Delta% \textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)||^{2}_{\Lambda_{i,j}^{-1}}C_{t}^{2}}{% \max\{\epsilon^{\prime},\frac{\Delta_{i}\vee\Delta_{j}+\epsilon^{\prime}}{3}\}% ^{2}}≤ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) | | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) | | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_max { italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , divide start_ARG roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG

Let τ′superscript𝜏′\tau^{\prime}italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT denote the total number of samples in round l𝑙litalic_l, encompassing both the offline dataset and the samples acquired during the execution of LG. Consequently, upon termination of the algorithm, the cumulative number of samples associated with element a𝑎aitalic_a is bounded by:

Tl′,a⁢(τ′)≤maxi,j∈[n]⁡p∗⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)⁢‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)‖Λi,j−12⁢Cτ′2max{ϵ′,Δi∨Δj+ϵ′3}2+1.\displaystyle T_{l^{\prime},a}(\tau^{\prime})\leq\max_{i,j\in[n]}\frac{p^{*}(l% ^{\prime},a|l,i,j)||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)||^{2}_{\Lambda% _{i,j}^{-1}}C_{\tau^{\prime}}^{2}}{\max\{\epsilon^{\prime},\frac{\Delta_{i}% \vee\Delta_{j}+\epsilon^{\prime}}{3}\}^{2}}+1.italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) ≤ roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) | | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) | | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_max { italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , divide start_ARG roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + 1 . (9)

Notice that we can reuse Nl′,a(l)superscriptsubscript𝑁superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙N_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)}italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT samples from the past rounds, therefore, the total number of samples of element a𝑎aitalic_a in round l𝑙litalic_l in LG is bounded by

max⁡{Tl′,a⁢(τ′)−Nl′,a(l),0}.subscript𝑇superscript𝑙′𝑎superscript𝜏′superscriptsubscript𝑁superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙0\displaystyle\max\{T_{l^{\prime},a}(\tau^{\prime})-N_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)},0\}.roman_max { italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0 } .

The total number of samples for all the elements in round l𝑙litalic_l during the execution of LG is bounded by

τ≤∑l′∈[l]∑a∈[n]max⁡{Tl′,a⁢(τ′)−Nl′,a(l),0}.𝜏subscriptsuperscript𝑙′delimited-[]𝑙subscript𝑎delimited-[]𝑛subscript𝑇superscript𝑙′𝑎superscript𝜏′superscriptsubscript𝑁superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙0\displaystyle\tau\leq\sum_{l^{\prime}\in[l]}\sum_{a\in[n]}\max\{T_{l^{\prime},% a}(\tau^{\prime})-N_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)},0\}.italic_τ ≤ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_l ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max { italic_T start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ( italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) - italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0 } .

Combine this inequality with (9), we get that

τ𝜏\displaystyle\tauitalic_τ ≤∑l′∈[l]∑a∈[n]max⁡{maxi,j∈[n]⁡p∗⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)⁢‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)‖Λi,j−12⁢Cτ′2max{ϵ′,Δi∨Δj+ϵ′3}2+1−Nl′,a(l),0}\displaystyle\leq\sum_{l^{\prime}\in[l]}\sum_{a\in[n]}\max\{\max_{i,j\in[n]}% \frac{p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)||% ^{2}_{\Lambda_{i,j}^{-1}}C_{\tau^{\prime}}^{2}}{\max\{\epsilon^{\prime},\frac{% \Delta_{i}\vee\Delta_{j}+\epsilon^{\prime}}{3}\}^{2}}+1-N_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)}% ,0\}≤ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_l ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max { roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) | | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) | | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_max { italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , divide start_ARG roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + 1 - italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0 }

where N(l)=∑l′∈[l]∑a∈[n]Nl′,a(l)superscript𝑁𝑙subscriptsuperscript𝑙′delimited-[]𝑙subscript𝑎delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝑁superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙N^{(l)}=\sum_{l^{\prime}\in[l]}\sum_{a\in[n]}N_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)}italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_l ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the total number of samples in the offline dataset.

From Lemma 13 and the discussion given in Appendix B in Xu et al. [2018], we have that the allocation ratio p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the optimal solution of the optimization problem as defined in (4) and (5), then it follows that

‖Δ⁢F⁢(S,i)−Δ⁢F⁢(S,j)‖Λi,j−12≤ρi,jl.subscriptsuperscriptnormΔF𝑆𝑖ΔF𝑆𝑗2superscriptsubscriptΛ𝑖𝑗1superscriptsubscript𝜌𝑖𝑗𝑙\displaystyle||\Delta\textbf{F}(S,i)-\Delta\textbf{F}(S,j)||^{2}_{\Lambda_{i,j% }^{-1}}\leq\rho_{i,j}^{l}.| | roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_i ) - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_j ) | | start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Λ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT .

where ρi,jlsuperscriptsubscript𝜌𝑖𝑗𝑙\rho_{i,j}^{l}italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the optimal value of (5) in the round l𝑙litalic_l.

Let us denote Hl′,a(l)=maxi,j∈[n]⁡p∗⁢(l′,a|l,i,j)⁢ρi,jlmax{ϵ/κ,Δl,i∨Δl,j+ϵ/κ3}2H_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)}=\max_{i,j\in[n]}\frac{p^{*}(l^{\prime},a|l,i,j)\rho_{i,% j}^{l}}{\max\{\epsilon/\kappa,\frac{\Delta_{l,i}\vee\Delta_{l,j}+\epsilon/% \kappa}{3}\}^{2}}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = roman_max start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a | italic_l , italic_i , italic_j ) italic_ρ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_l end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_max { italic_ϵ / italic_κ , divide start_ARG roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∨ roman_Δ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l , italic_j end_POSTSUBSCRIPT + italic_ϵ / italic_κ end_ARG start_ARG 3 end_ARG } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG and Hϵ(l)=∑l′∈[l],a∈[n]Hl′,a(l)superscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑙subscriptformulae-sequencesuperscript𝑙′delimited-[]𝑙𝑎delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐻superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙H_{\epsilon}^{(l)}=\sum_{l^{\prime}\in[l],a\in[n]}H_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_l ] , italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. Then the inequality above is

τ𝜏\displaystyle\tauitalic_τ ≤∑l′∈[l]∑a∈[n]max⁡{Hl′,a(l)⁢Cτ+N2+1−Nl′,a(l),0}.absentsubscriptsuperscript𝑙′delimited-[]𝑙subscript𝑎delimited-[]𝑛superscriptsubscript𝐻superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐶𝜏𝑁21superscriptsubscript𝑁superscript𝑙′𝑎𝑙0\displaystyle\leq\sum_{l^{\prime}\in[l]}\sum_{a\in[n]}\max\{H_{l^{\prime},a}^{% (l)}C_{\tau+N}^{2}+1-N_{l^{\prime},a}^{(l)},0\}.≤ ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∈ [ italic_l ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_a ∈ [ italic_n ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max { italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ + italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + 1 - italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_l start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , italic_a end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0 } . (10)

It then follows that

τ𝜏\displaystyle\tauitalic_τ ≤Hϵ(l)⁢Cτ+N2+n⁢l.absentsuperscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑙superscriptsubscript𝐶𝜏𝑁2𝑛𝑙\displaystyle\leq H_{\epsilon}^{(l)}C_{\tau+N}^{2}+nl.≤ italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_τ + italic_N end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_n italic_l . (11)

By definition, we have that

Ct=R⁢2⁢log⁡det(At)12⁢det(λ⁢I)−12δ+λ12⁢S.subscript𝐶𝑡𝑅2superscriptsubscriptA𝑡12superscript𝜆𝐼12𝛿superscript𝜆12𝑆\displaystyle C_{t}=R\sqrt{2\log\frac{\det(\textbf{A}_{t})^{\frac{1}{2}}\det(% \lambda I)^{-\frac{1}{2}}}{\delta}}+\lambda^{\frac{1}{2}}S.italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_R square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log divide start_ARG roman_det ( A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_det ( italic_λ italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG end_ARG + italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S .

By Lemma 12, we can get that

Ct≤R⁢2⁢log⁡1δ+d⁢log⁡(1+t⁢L2λ⁢d)+λ12⁢S.subscript𝐶𝑡𝑅21𝛿𝑑1𝑡superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑑superscript𝜆12𝑆\displaystyle C_{t}\leq R\sqrt{2\log\frac{1}{\delta}+d\log(1+\frac{tL^{2}}{% \lambda d})}+\lambda^{\frac{1}{2}}S.italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_R square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG + italic_d roman_log ( 1 + divide start_ARG italic_t italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG ) end_ARG + italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S .

Since λ≤2⁢R2S2⁢log⁡1δ𝜆2superscript𝑅2superscript𝑆21𝛿\lambda\leq\frac{2R^{2}}{S^{2}}\log\frac{1}{\delta}italic_λ ≤ divide start_ARG 2 italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG, it follows that

Ct≤2⁢R⁢2⁢log⁡1δ+d⁢log⁡(1+t⁢L2λ⁢d).subscript𝐶𝑡2𝑅21𝛿𝑑1𝑡superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑑\displaystyle C_{t}\leq 2R\sqrt{2\log\frac{1}{\delta}+d\log(1+\frac{tL^{2}}{% \lambda d})}.italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ 2 italic_R square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG + italic_d roman_log ( 1 + divide start_ARG italic_t italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG ) end_ARG . (12)

Combine (11) with (12), we can get

τ≤4⁢Hϵ(l)⁢R2⁢(2⁢log⁡1δ+d⁢log⁡(1+(τ+N(l))⁢L2λ⁢d))+n⁢l𝜏4superscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑙superscript𝑅221𝛿𝑑1𝜏superscript𝑁𝑙superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑑𝑛𝑙\displaystyle\tau\leq 4H_{\epsilon}^{(l)}R^{2}\big{(}2\log\frac{1}{\delta}+d% \log(1+\frac{(\tau+N^{(l)})L^{2}}{\lambda d})\big{)}+nlitalic_τ ≤ 4 italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG + italic_d roman_log ( 1 + divide start_ARG ( italic_τ + italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG ) ) + italic_n italic_l

It then follows that

(τ+N(l))⁢L2λ⁢d+1≤4⁢Hϵ(l)⁢R2⁢L2λ⁢d⁢(2⁢log⁡1δ+d⁢log⁡(1+(τ+N(l))⁢L2λ⁢d))+(N(l)+n⁢l)⁢L2λ⁢d+1𝜏superscript𝑁𝑙superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑑14superscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑙superscript𝑅2superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑑21𝛿𝑑1𝜏superscript𝑁𝑙superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑑superscript𝑁𝑙𝑛𝑙superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑑1\displaystyle\frac{(\tau+N^{(l)})L^{2}}{\lambda d}+1\leq\frac{4H_{\epsilon}^{(% l)}R^{2}L^{2}}{\lambda d}\big{(}2\log\frac{1}{\delta}+d\log(1+\frac{(\tau+N^{(% l)})L^{2}}{\lambda d})\big{)}+\frac{(N^{(l)}+nl)L^{2}}{\lambda d}+1divide start_ARG ( italic_τ + italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG + 1 ≤ divide start_ARG 4 italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG ( 2 roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG + italic_d roman_log ( 1 + divide start_ARG ( italic_τ + italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG ) ) + divide start_ARG ( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_n italic_l ) italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG + 1

By Lemma 15, we have that

Plugging the above inequality into (10), it follows that

where M=16⁢Hϵ(l)⁢R2⁢L2λ⁢log⁡1δ+32(Hϵ(l))2R4L4λ2+2⁢(N(l)+n⁢l)⁢L2λ⁢d+2.M=\frac{16H_{\epsilon}^{(l)}R^{2}L^{2}}{\lambda}\log\frac{1}{\delta}+\frac{32(% H_{\epsilon}^{(l))^{2}}R^{4}L^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}+\frac{2(N^{(l)}+nl)L^{2}}{% \lambda d}+2.italic_M = divide start_ARG 16 italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG + divide start_ARG 32 ( italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_l ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_n italic_l ) italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG + 2 . ∎

Appendix B Appendix for Section 4

In this section, we present the proofs of theoretical results from Section 4. First, in Section B.1, we present and prove the Lemma 6 concerning the theoretical guarantee on the value of the evaluated marginal gain and sample complexity of LinTG. Next, we apply the theoretical results of Lemma 6 and prove the final theoretical guarantee for the linear threshold greedy algorithm LinTG in Algorithm 2.

B.1 Proof of Lemma 6

We prove the theoretical guarantee about evaluation of each marginal gain in LinTG. First of all, we present the detailed statements of Lemma 6. First, we notice that by Lemma 13, we have that p∗superscript𝑝p^{*}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT at the m𝑚mitalic_m-th evaluation of marginal gain can be calculated by

pi∗=|wi∗|∑i∈[m]|wi∗|subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑖subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑖subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑤𝑖\displaystyle p^{*}_{i}=\frac{|w^{*}_{i}|}{\sum_{i\in[m]}|w^{*}_{i}|}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = divide start_ARG | italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG start_ARG ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_w start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | end_ARG (13)

where wi∗superscriptsubscript𝑤𝑖w_{i}^{*}italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the optimal solution to the linear programming problem below.

argmin{wi}∑i∈[m]|wi|s.t.ΔF(Sm,am)=∑i=1mwiΔF(Si,ai).\displaystyle\arg\min_{\{w_{i}\}}\sum_{i\in[m]}|w_{i}|\qquad s.t.\qquad\Delta% \textbf{F}(S_{m},a_{m})=\sum_{i=1}^{m}w_{i}\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{i},a_{i}).roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s . italic_t . roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . Lemma 6.

During the m𝑚mitalic_m-th evaluation on the marginal gain of adding element amsubscript𝑎𝑚a_{m}italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT to Smsubscript𝑆𝑚S_{m}italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT in LinTG, we have that with probability at least 1−δ/21𝛿21-\delta/21 - italic_δ / 2, the following statement holds.

  1. 1.

    Assuming λ≤2⁢R2S2⁢log⁡2δ𝜆2superscript𝑅2superscript𝑆22𝛿\lambda\leq\frac{2R^{2}}{S^{2}}\log\frac{2}{\delta}italic_λ ≤ divide start_ARG 2 italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_S start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG, then it takes at most

    ∑i∈[m]max⁡{4⁢Hi(m)⁢R2⁢(2⁢log⁡2δ+d⁢log⁡M(m))+1−Ni(m),0}subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚4subscriptsuperscript𝐻𝑚𝑖superscript𝑅222𝛿𝑑superscript𝑀𝑚1superscriptsubscript𝑁𝑖𝑚0\displaystyle\sum_{i\in[m]}\max\{4H^{(m)}_{i}R^{2}(2\log\frac{2}{\delta}+d\log M% ^{(m)})+1-N_{i}^{(m)},0\}∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_max { 4 italic_H start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( 2 roman_log divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG + italic_d roman_log italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) + 1 - italic_N start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT , 0 }

    samples to evaluate the m𝑚mitalic_m-th marginal gain, where M(m)=16⁢Hϵ(m)⁢R2⁢L2λ⁢log⁡2δ+32⁢(Hϵ(m))2⁢R4⁢L4λ2+2⁢(N(m)+m)⁢L2λ⁢d+2superscript𝑀𝑚16superscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑚superscript𝑅2superscript𝐿2𝜆2𝛿32superscriptsuperscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑚2superscript𝑅4superscript𝐿4superscript𝜆22superscript𝑁𝑚𝑚superscript𝐿2𝜆𝑑2M^{(m)}=\frac{16H_{\epsilon}^{(m)}R^{2}L^{2}}{\lambda}\log\frac{2}{\delta}+% \frac{32(H_{\epsilon}^{(m)})^{2}R^{4}L^{4}}{\lambda^{2}}+\frac{2(N^{(m)}+m)L^{% 2}}{\lambda d}+2italic_M start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG 16 italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ end_ARG roman_log divide start_ARG 2 end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG + divide start_ARG 32 ( italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_R start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 4 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG + divide start_ARG 2 ( italic_N start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_m ) italic_L start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_λ italic_d end_ARG + 2. Here Hi(m)=pi∗⁢ρ(m)max{ϵ/κ+|w−Δ⁢F⁢(S,a)T⁢w|2,ϵ/κ}2H_{i}^{(m)}=\frac{p^{*}_{i}\rho^{(m)}}{\max\{\frac{\epsilon/\kappa+|w-\Delta% \textbf{F}(S,a)^{T}\textbf{w}|}{2},\epsilon/\kappa\}^{2}}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = divide start_ARG italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG roman_max { divide start_ARG italic_ϵ / italic_κ + | italic_w - roman_Δ F ( italic_S , italic_a ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w | end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , italic_ϵ / italic_κ } start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT 2 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG and Hϵ(m)=∑i∈[m]Hi(m)superscriptsubscript𝐻italic-ϵ𝑚subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚superscriptsubscript𝐻𝑖𝑚H_{\epsilon}^{(m)}=\sum_{i\in[m]}H_{i}^{(m)}italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_ϵ end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_H start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT. pi∗subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑖p^{*}_{i}italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the fraction of samples allocated to sample Δ⁢F⁢(Si,ai)ΔFsubscript𝑆𝑖subscript𝑎𝑖\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{i},a_{i})roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) and therefore ∑i∈[m]pi∗=1subscript𝑖delimited-[]𝑚subscriptsuperscript𝑝𝑖1\sum_{i\in[m]}p^{*}_{i}=1∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_p start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ∗ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = 1. ρ(m)superscript𝜌𝑚\rho^{(m)}italic_ρ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( italic_m ) end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT is the optimal value of

    argmin{wi}∑i∈[m]|wi|s.t.ΔF(Sm,am)=∑i=1mwiΔF(Si,ai).\displaystyle\arg\min_{\{w_{i}\}}\sum_{i\in[m]}|w_{i}|\qquad s.t.\qquad\Delta% \textbf{F}(S_{m},a_{m})=\sum_{i=1}^{m}w_{i}\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{i},a_{i}).roman_arg roman_min start_POSTSUBSCRIPT { italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT } end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i ∈ [ italic_m ] end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | italic_s . italic_t . roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) = ∑ start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i = 1 end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_w start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_i end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) . (15)
  2. 2.

    If the element is added to the solution set, then Δ⁢F⁢(Sm,am)T⁢w≥w−ϵ/κΔFsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚𝑇w𝑤italic-ϵ𝜅\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{m},a_{m})^{T}\textbf{w}\geq w-\epsilon/\kapparoman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w ≥ italic_w - italic_ϵ / italic_κ. Otherwise, Δ⁢F⁢(Sm,am)T⁢w≤w+ϵ/κΔFsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚𝑇w𝑤italic-ϵ𝜅\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{m},a_{m})^{T}\textbf{w}\leq w+\epsilon/\kapparoman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w ≤ italic_w + italic_ϵ / italic_κ.

For notation simplicity, throughout the proof, we define ϵ′=ϵ/κsuperscriptitalic-ϵ′italic-ϵ𝜅\epsilon^{\prime}=\epsilon/\kappaitalic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT = italic_ϵ / italic_κ. To prove this lemma, We first present the following Lemma 7 and Lemma 8 about our algorithm LinTG. Once these lemmas are proven, we next prove the main result of Lemma 6 using the lemmas. We start by introducing the following ”clean event”.

ℰ={|Δ⁢F⁢(Sm,am)T⁢(w^−w)|≤βt,∀t}ℰΔFsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚𝑇^wwsubscript𝛽𝑡for-all𝑡\displaystyle\mathcal{E}=\{|\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{m},a_{m})^{T}(\hat{\textbf{w}}% -\textbf{w})|\leq\beta_{t},\forall t\}caligraphic_E = { | roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ( over^ start_ARG w end_ARG - w ) | ≤ italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , ∀ italic_t }

Here βtsubscript𝛽𝑡\beta_{t}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT is the confidence interval and is defined as βt=Ct⁢‖Δ⁢F⁢(Sm,am)‖At−1=(R⁢2⁢log⁡2⁢det(At)12⁢det(λ⁢I)−12δ+λ12⁢S)⁢‖Δ⁢F⁢(Sm,am)‖At−1subscript𝛽𝑡subscript𝐶𝑡subscriptnormΔFsubscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚superscriptsubscriptA𝑡1𝑅22superscriptsubscriptA𝑡12superscript𝜆𝐼12𝛿superscript𝜆12𝑆subscriptnormΔFsubscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚superscriptsubscriptA𝑡1\beta_{t}=C_{t}||\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{m},a_{m})||_{\textbf{A}_{t}^{-1}}=(R\sqrt% {2\log\frac{2\det(\textbf{A}_{t})^{\frac{1}{2}}\det(\lambda I)^{-\frac{1}{2}}}% {\delta}}+\lambda^{\frac{1}{2}}S)||\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{m},a_{m})||_{\textbf{A}% _{t}^{-1}}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = italic_C start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT | | roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT = ( italic_R square-root start_ARG 2 roman_log divide start_ARG 2 roman_det ( A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT roman_det ( italic_λ italic_I ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_ARG start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG end_ARG + italic_λ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT divide start_ARG 1 end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_S ) | | roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) | | start_POSTSUBSCRIPT A start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - 1 end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT end_POSTSUBSCRIPT. From the fact that Δ⁢F⁢(Sm,am)ΔFsubscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚\Delta\textbf{F}(S_{m},a_{m})roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) only depends on the offline dataset, i.e., the history up to time t𝑡titalic_t, we can apply the result in Proposition 1. It follows that P⁢(ℰ)≥1−δ2𝑃ℰ1𝛿2P(\mathcal{E})\geq 1-\frac{\delta}{2}italic_P ( caligraphic_E ) ≥ 1 - divide start_ARG italic_δ end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG. Therefore, we have the following lemma.

Lemma 7.

With probability at least 1−δ/21𝛿21-\delta/21 - italic_δ / 2, it holds that

P⁢(ℰ)≥1−δ.𝑃ℰ1𝛿\displaystyle P(\mathcal{E})\geq 1-\delta.italic_P ( caligraphic_E ) ≥ 1 - italic_δ .

Next, we prove the bound on the confidence interval βtsubscript𝛽𝑡\beta_{t}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.

Conditioned on the event ℰℰ\mathcal{E}caligraphic_E, the confidence interval βtsubscript𝛽𝑡\beta_{t}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT satisfies that

βt≥max⁡{ϵ′+|w−Δ⁢F⁢(Sm,am)T⁢w|2,ϵ′}subscript𝛽𝑡superscriptitalic-ϵ′𝑤ΔFsuperscriptsubscript𝑆𝑚subscript𝑎𝑚𝑇w2superscriptitalic-ϵ′\displaystyle\beta_{t}\geq\max\{\frac{\epsilon^{\prime}+|w-\Delta\textbf{F}(S_% {m},a_{m})^{T}\textbf{w}|}{2},\epsilon^{\prime}\}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ roman_max { divide start_ARG italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + | italic_w - roman_Δ F ( italic_S start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT , italic_a start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_m end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ) start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT italic_T end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT w | end_ARG start_ARG 2 end_ARG , italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT }

before the evaluation of the marginal gain ends.

Proof.

In the case where βt≤ϵ′subscript𝛽𝑡superscriptitalic-ϵ′\beta_{t}\leq\epsilon^{\prime}italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≤ italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT, then w+ϵ′−βt≥w−ϵ′+βt𝑤superscriptitalic-ϵ′subscript𝛽𝑡𝑤superscriptitalic-ϵ′subscript𝛽𝑡w+\epsilon^{\prime}-\beta_{t}\geq w-\epsilon^{\prime}+\beta_{t}italic_w + italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT - italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT ≥ italic_w - italic_ϵ start_POSTSUPERSCRIPT ′ end_POSTSUPERSCRIPT + italic_β start_POSTSUBSCRIPT italic_t end_POSTSUBSCRIPT.
